DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN CAPITAL TERRITORY GOVERNMENT SERVICE (CONSEQUENTIAL PROVISIONS) AMENDMENT BILL 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 26 June, on motion by Mr Reith:
That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Keefe, Neil, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —As has been made clear, the opposition is in agreement with the provisions of the Australian Capital Territory Government Service (Consequential Provisions) Amendment Bill 1996 and is happy to roll with it, so my contribution this morning is more broadly based in relation to the ACT and the people who work here. I have to observe—and this is one of my first opportunities to do so since a number of announcements have been made by the government about the fate of people working in the Capital Territory—that it is interesting that the domestic economy here is in a state of trauma over housing prices and the whole box and dice, as people are hunting around for packages and looking for some way to move out of Canberra because of the frenzy these people have about public servants.

SPEECH.PARA: The strange thing about it is that you would have thought that, from their time in opposition, the government would have at least understood who actually worked and lived in the ACT and who were public servants. What is very evident is that they have arrived in town in their new Rolls and they have decided, true to their commitment—one of the few promises they are keeping—to slash the federal Public Service. And have they done so! The only thing that they were too silly to understand was that 75 per cent of people who work in the federal Public Service do not live or work in Canberra but in fact deliver their services out in the regions and in places such as Bendigo, Ballarat, Bathurst, Cairns, Rockhampton, Townsville, Port Augusta and elsewhere. Of course, the transitional provisions for employment that are covered in this bill make a hell of a lot of sense—as long as you can sell your house in Canberra and as long as you can find a job somewhere else.

I was in Bendigo last week when we observed what I would have called a routine public meeting, which had an astounding turnout. Part of it was generated by the `Bruce Reid black hole', as it is now being called in downtown Bendigo: the black hole of jobs and the black hole of Public Service morale and unfunded promises. Built into the budget provisions—not in relation to this particular bill—there are not only evil and downright unfair decisions, such as the dental scheme one, but also others, such as one I came across the other day that I thought harboured the most absurd decision I have heard or seen any federal government making.

I do not know whether the Australian Capital Territory (Consequential Provisions) Amendment Bill has any coverage of the CDEP—the community development employment program—for Aboriginal people, but I had to laugh at the inanity of the decision about a program where one group in the Australian community actually came to the federal government and said, `We want to work for the dole. Our people do not want sit‐down money. They want to work for the dole. Can we have a work for the dole scheme called the CDEP?' It was put in place, but guess what the government have done in the budget: they have scrapped the CDEP.

What have they done instead? They have increased unemployment benefits by $57 million for Aboriginal people so that they can have the dole but not work for it, against their wishes. When they get out there amongst redneck Australians, whom they continually placate with this frenzy about public servants and about Aboriginals, and start trying to explain to them why they have done very stupid things—such as slashing the federal Public Service, not realising that the people affected do not actually work in Canberra, and slashing the employment programs for Aboriginal people so that they can have the dole for sitting down rather than working—presumably someone within their ranks will start to ask some questions.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! While I appreciate that the honourable member might think that he has had a long preamble, he did ask the rhetorical question about whether some of the matters he raised had anything to do with the bill, and it is stretching my imagination a little to find the relevance. I would ask that the honourable member come back to the bill.

—Yes, I appreciate that that is the case and I accept your gentle guidance in this matter. So much so that I am prepared to end my contribution at this point by simply making it clear that we, on this side of the house, are supportive of these transitional provisions. We have undertaken to give them support and so I am happy to use the opportunity to make a brief contribution to the proceedings of the parliament. Thank you.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Charles, Bob, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —This bill, the Australian Capital Territory Government Service (Consequential Provisions) Amendment Bill 1996, deserves the support of the opposition and I thank the member for Burke (Mr O'Keefe) for confirming that, in fact, the opposition will be supporting the bill.

SPEECH.PARA: In 1994, the ACT Government Service Act was established and, essentially, this allowed for mobility between ACT government employees and the more general Australian Public Service. It has become apparent in recent times, as the ACT corporatises part of its bureaucracy to make it more efficient and to make it operate better for the people of the Australian Capital Territory, that some of the provisions that employees of the bureaucracy thought would apply in fact did not. So this act allows the making of regulations which will allow people to hang on to their prior public service and to use that, if they decided to leave the branch or the corporatised body they were in, to compete on an equal basis with other people seeking jobs that become available in the broader Australian Public Service, wherever that might be. The government presents this bill as a mechanism to allow those good and long‐serving people with the Australian government bureaucracy to have job portability, and I think that is certainly a supportable measure.

I was somewhat disappointed at the comments of the honourable member for Burke. He carried on somewhat about the loss of some public sector jobs. Let me say this to the Australian people: we were elected, I think, in large part, to try to do something about establishing a better base for the Australian economy and a better standard of living for all Australians. Last night, in a contribution to the budget debate, I made the point—and I would like to make it again—that I certainly believe that individuals have a better idea about how they would like to spend the money that they earn than does government. If we continue to tax the Australian people at a high rate and if we continue to decide how their money should be spent, then we deny them the opportunity to make decisions for themselves. I am well reminded that the corporate estate of the former Soviet Union did a very poor job of deciding how people's income should be spent. So much so, that that whole empire failed.

It is a fact that democratic governments around the world have proved successful because, to the largest extent, they allow their citizens freedom—freedom of choice and freedom of decision making. In this respect, if we are spending too much of the people's money on governing the people and providing services for the people which they might well provide for themselves, it is only fair and reasonable that we return to the people that decision making power. That, in essence, is what this is all about.

The member for Burke said that some of the government's programs were evil. What nonsense! He carried on apace about the member for Bendigo (Mr Reid). I will stand up for the member for Bendigo, a colleague of mine, whom I know to have done a fantastic job in that region of the state of Victoria. He has been returned on two occasions, having originally won his seat in 1990, and the people of Bendigo support their honourable member. He fights hard for them. He works hard in this place to support the regional initiatives that are important for the people in Bendigo and the surrounding regions and his constituents know that. They know that and they know him well, and I am sure that they will disregard the less than honourable comments of the member for Burke.

I would like to say something general about the ACT and the government in the ACT. Because we who represent the people live a portion of our lives in Canberra, we do get to know some of the people who live in Canberra, and to mix with them. We learn what the Canberra colony is all about and how the bureaucracy works—or does not work—in the Australian Capital Territory.

Coming as I do from a background in the building and construction industry, I have for a long time had concerns about how the development process works in the ACT. It seems to me that, to some extent, we have a case of bureaucracy gone mad at times. In order to get a building permit, an architect whom I know well sometimes has to draw plans four, five, six or seven times to meet unclear guidelines and to meet the personal whims of the particular person who will certify plans and allow them to proceed. He has to meet the requirements of unknown people behind the scenes whom he never gets to meet. The liability is huge, and that liability, of course, adds to the cost.

He is a well‐known, well‐established architect who understands the basics of good building construction and good design and wins national awards year after year. Can you imagine how disheartening it is to have to design a building and then redesign it and redesign it to meet criteria which keep shifting hour by hour, day by day, week by week and, sometimes, month by month? It is taking an incredible amount of time to get approval and to get a building permit to actually go ahead and build the buildings that my friend, the architect, so capably designs.

So perhaps this is an appropriate time to say generally to the ACT government that it is time to allow the private sector a little bit more leeway. We have never really proven that a person trying to act for the benefit of everyone else in creating regulations really does a better job for those people than the people would do for themselves. We can create rules and then build on the rules, because we do not like the shape or size or colour of a particular building. We can say, `Well, the ceilings must be no lower than eight feet,' or `They must be no higher than nine feet,' or `You must have five trees in the front garden and you must have a circular pathway.' This is all nonsense. It is regulation gone mad and the bureaucracy acting to feed upon itself. Perhaps that occurs somewhat because of insecurity.

It is time, surely, for the ACT government to look at its regulatory authority with respect to building construction, to try to give a little bit more latitude to those who so capably design the buildings that grace this fair city and make it work so well to provide comfort, housing and good working conditions for the people of Canberra, for the people who come to visit and for us, who are indeed temporary residents.
The government brought this bill before the parliament in good faith and I am pleased that the opposition will support it. I commend the bill to the Main Committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith, Tony, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Reith) is unable to be here to wrap this matter up and he has asked me to thank honourable members for their contribution to the debate and, in particular, members of the opposition for their support of the Australian Capital Territory Government Service (Consequential Provisions) Amendment Bill 1996.

SPEECH.PARA: In summary, in 1994 when officers of the Australian Public Service were compulsorily transferred to the ACT Government Service, the provisions of the Australian Capital Territory Government Service (Consequential Provisions) Act 1994, the ACTGS act, were introduced to allow ACT officers to apply for selection on merit for positions advertised in the Gazette as vacancies in the Australian Public Service. Similar provisions are made in ACT legislation for Australian Public Service officers to apply for ACT vacancies.

On 1 July 1995 the Australian Capital Territory government corporatised ACT Electricity and Water—ACTEW—and compulsorily transferred ACTEW employees from the ACT Government Service to a new company, ACTEW Corporation. As a consequence, the corporation employees were no longer covered by the terms of the ACTGS act mobility arrangements.

In July 1995 the committee agreed with the ACT Chief Minister to extend the mobility provisions for a period until 30 June 1998 to the employees of the corporation who lost the mobility rights when they were compulsorily transferred from the ACT Government Service.

The bill proposes an amendment in those terms to enable the reinstatement of certain staff mobility arrangements between the ACT Government Service and the Australian Public Service. The amendment adds a regulation making power to the act, to permit modification to the ACT Capital Territory Government Service (Consequential Provisions) Act 1994 and to any other act in relation to a matter arising from an ACT officer becoming an employee of a body corporate controlled by the territory.
I commend the bill to the Main Committee.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
Bill—by leave—reported to the House without amendment.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 26 June, on motion by Mr Williams:
That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McClelland, Robert, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the motion. The purpose of the Legislative Instruments Bill 1996 is to reform the Commonwealth's procedure for making, scrutinising, publishing, amending and repealing subordinate legislation. The bill consolidates into one act existing procedural requirements which are found in the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 and the Statutory Rules Publication Act 1903. The measures will essentially allow a greater scrutiny of, and public access to, delegated legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: The bill has a number of primary aims: firstly, defining more clearly and comprehensively the forms of subordinate legislation subject to parliamentary review and disallowance; secondly, allowing the Attorney‐General to issue a certificate in specified circumstances to clarify the nature of an instrument; thirdly, establishing a single register of delegated legislation, with legislative instruments only being enforceable if they are on the register; fourthly, introducing public notice and consultation procedures for changes to delegated legislation affecting business; fifthly, providing for the back‐capture or updating of existing subordinate legislation and its placement on the public register; sixthly, introducing automatic sunsetting provisions requiring all legislative instruments to be reviewed every five years; seventhly, providing for parliamentary scrutiny of all forms of delegated legislation, with each instrument to be tabled in each house of parliament within six days of registration; and, finally, making consequential amendments to other related acts.

The background to the legislation is that at present there are very few limitations on the power of the Commonwealth parliament to make delegated legislation, which takes the form of rules and regulations by subordinate bodies, including statutory authorities, administrative tribunals and, most relevantly, the executive. Existing limitations, such as they are, are derived from the fact that Commonwealth legislation must be based upon or reasonably incidental to some constitutional power, such as the numerous heads of power contained in section 51 or section 52, or even section 122, of the constitution.

Basically, the principle in respect to delegated legislation is one predicated on the fact that we have, in this country, and very fortunately, a system of responsible government. That is found in a number of constitutional heads, including section 1, which provides that the legislative power of the Commonwealth shall be vested in the federal parliament, which consists of the Queen, the Senate and the House of Representatives. Section 7 provides for the democratic election of senators and section 24 provides for the democratic election of members of the House of Representatives. The constitution quite clearly in a number of sections is based on the principle of representative democracy in a form involving direct popular election and the principle of responsible government as reflected in sections 62 and 64 of the constitution.

What is apparent from the constitution is that government is quite literally meant to be by a parliament directly accountable to its popular mandate. Indeed, that has never been doubted. This system of responsible government has been referred to in a number of High Court cases as pervading the constitution, and fortunately so. One of the earlier statements was in the famous Boilermakers case: R. v. Kirby, ex parte the Boilermakers' Society of Australia.

There has been, over the years, great difficulty in determining just when delegated legislation falls into the category of being a statutory instrument of an administrative nature and when it has a legislative character. In a recent case in Sanyo Australia Pty Ltd v. Comptroller‐General of Customs, the High Court said that the case emphasised:

BREAK.PARA: . . . the distinction between legislation which in general involves the laying down of general rules which have legal and binding effect and the taking of administrative action which, insofar as it has legal and binding effect, is taken in execution or application of the law and, insofar as it lays down general rules, tends not to have a legally binding effect but to lay down rules in the nature of policy or of guidelines.

That statement of principle is a correct judicial pronouncement, but the difficulty comes in applying it. This bill will go quite some way to resolving the uncertainty in assessing and applying delegated legislation.

The fundamental restriction on the legality of delegated legislation is the fact that parliament cannot delegate its legislative power. It cannot simply abdicate, to statutory authorities or to ministers, the power to make laws. But if one analyses a number of acts of parliament one finds there are very wide powers given. Indeed, the research section of the library has referred to a number of those.

For instance, section 70 of the Administrative Appeals Tribunal Act gives the Governor‐General power to make regulations required or permitted by that act to be prescribed, or necessary or convenient to be prescribed, for carrying out or giving effect to that act, which is an extremely broad delegation indeed. Item 20 of the schedule to the Excise Tariff Act refers to the imposition of an excise as prescribed by departmental law.

Section 59 of the Federal Court of Australia Act allows the judges of the court, or a majority of them, to make rules of court governing procedure and other administrative matters. Those rules and procedures go a very substantial way to determining how justice is administered and, indeed, what sorts of remedies can be given. That is also a very broad delegation.

A further example is contained in section 180 of the Migration Act, which gives the minister special power to refuse or cancel a visa or entry permit. We, as members of parliament, would have seen the width with which that power has been exercised. In summary, it is essential that there be a regime of more closely scrutinising delegated legislation and, indeed, having public input before delegated legislation is made.

I note that the history of this legislation goes back quite some years. Proposals for a legislative instruments bill arose in 1992 with the Administrative Review Council's report, Rule making by Commonwealth agencies. The council found that delegated legislation varied in quality and was inaccessible and obscure. It recommended the enactment of a legislative instruments act to address the problems that it had found and reported on.

A bill substantially based on that report was introduced in the Senate and read a first time on 30 June 1994. It was subsequently referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances. That committee presented its report to the Senate on 17 October 1994. The committee endorsed the objectives of the bill and generally supported its main principles.

The government's response was tabled on 8 November 1994 and the bill was read a second time in the Senate on 9 November 1994. The bill was subsequently deferred, and the government agreed not to proceed until the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs had reported on the bill. A speaker who will be succeeding me, the honourable member for Banks (Mr Melham), and, indeed, the Attorney‐General (Mr Williams), both had considerable input on that committee. That committee was also asked to report on the proposed government amendments, some of which responded to the recommendations of the Senate regulations and ordinances committee report and other related matters.

The bill, however, was awaiting passage prior to the 1996 election. The bill as moved by the government essentially derives from that bill although, it must be said, with some additional modifications. The current bill draws on those earlier reports, and the main features it adds are sunsetting and a more structured consultation regime. It is appropriately a shift of control over delegated legislation back to the parliament, and increases government accountability through improved access and consultation mechanisms. It is consistent with those High Court authorities and constitutional provisions, to which I referred earlier, regarding the concept of responsible government which pervades our constitution and the concept of government by the people through their elected representatives.

The bill will apply the same regime to all delegated legislative instruments, instead of the varying requirements that presently apply. The bill's coverage is determined by a definition of a legislative instrument essentially based on the legislative character of the instrument and goes some way to clarifying the extent of appropriate delegation.

As the Attorney‐General noted in his second reading speech, the bill introduces a mandatory consultation procedure for instruments directly affecting business or having a substantial indirect effect on business. Consultation will ensure the consideration of all relevant issues before the delegated legislation is made. However, this is perhaps one area where there is some criticism, from my perspective, of the bill in that there is no logical reason to so restrict the scope of consultation. I note, however, that the minister has referred to this being, if you like, a trial or limited operation for the present time and its broadening may well be subject to further consideration. I sincerely hope that will be the case.

While I note the government is anxious to indicate to small business that it is keen on reducing the extent of regulation, which we would also support, it is important not to become one‐eyed or too limited as a result of the desire to present that image. The minister in fact said that, in light of the experience gained in the more targeted approach to small business issues, it may well be expanded. Again, I would encourage the Attorney‐General to take that course of action.

The concept of access to legislative instruments is one which is welcomed. From my point of view as a legal practitioner, I can say that it was quite frequently a nightmare advising clients, particularly in areas which were a little out of the mainstream where there were no services updating developments. More than one solicitor over time has got into trouble by providing advice to their client only to find—

TALK.START.PARA: —One or two counsels, too!

—Yes, I would certainly agree that more than one or two counsel have got into trouble in advising their clients with all the best will and every due diligence, only to find that some regulation or rule had been passed which fundamentally shifted the thrust of legislation.

BREAK.PARA: A common example has been that in various taxation areas legislative instruments have fundamentally altered the criteria for selection for the assessing or enforcement of taxation imposts. So again this concept of access, when access itself is based upon the departments bringing regulations up to date before they are put on the public register, will considerably advance the quality of legal advice which can be provided and will provide a ready measure as to competence. Any lawyer who advises a client in a particular area without first checking that public register would be very foolish indeed. In that context I see the public register operating in much the same way as, for instance, the REVS program, when one checks on whether a car is encumbered by a mortgage or whether any charge applies. That can be done immediately when someone is purchasing.

These are very significant advances. This is an indication of government keeping pace with developments, not only in terms of the impact that federal law has on the operation of government generally but also by keeping pace with technology. The reference in legislation to the existence of a public register which utilises that technology is a significant advance and is to be encouraged.

I wholeheartedly support the legislation. In fairness to the Attorney‐General, I note that he indicated that it was substantially based on the history of developments to which I have referred in this speech. I know he will not praise himself but, again, one of the speakers to follow me, the member for Banks (Mr Melham), had a considerable input into the development of the concepts which are now contained in the bill. Again I indicate my support for the proposal.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cadman, Alan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a very proud day for the Attorney‐General (Mr Williams), I would imagine. Of all the people in this parliament he is pre‐eminent in his press to have the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs examine in detail the legislative instruments legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: I acknowledge the presence in the Committee of the former chairman of that House of Representatives committee, the member for Banks (Mr Melham), and I want to pay tribute also to him because he was a very fine chairman of the committee. In my opinion, he and the member for Shortland (Mr Peter Morris), of Labor Party membership, exemplified the finest traditions of chairmanship of parliamentary committees. It was through the preparedness of the member for Banks as chairman of that committee, and also through the far‐sightedness and enthusiasm of the member for Tangney, the now Attorney‐General, that we moved to examine this legislation.

I am very pleased with the results of that and I think that the member for Banks would have to acknowledge that it is a nice turn of events—in more ways than one, particularly for those on this side of the House—that the Labor Party introduced this legislation, took the first step and followed through on the recommendations of the tribunal. I think that the Administrative Review Council's report Rule making by Commonwealth agencies sparked the previous government.

It determined to do something, because the whole process of law-making in Australia in this area—delegated law—has been a mess; complicated and deadly for practitioners. People have unexpectedly been trapped, and there was uncertainty for us as law-makers in many instances. It had become the practice of the previous government to put framework legislation in place and dump the real substance of legislation into regulations or delegated instruments. That process meant that there was real uncertainty on our part in making laws. It did, in fact, give the bureaucracy more free rein than sense dictated it should have; but it also meant that there was great uncertainty for those recipients and so-called beneficiaries of our laws.

The meeting together of a chairman of the legal and constitutional affairs committee and a fine legal mind from Western Australia, in the form of Mr Daryl Williams, QC, meant that we were able to conduct a very far‐reaching inquiry in that committee. It was done with the utmost goodwill, with us all seeking to tease out what were the relevant points, and with the report being tabled in the parliament in 1995.

BREAK.PARA: It was a response to the Labor Party's Legislative Instruments Bill of 1994. The bill was awaiting passage in the Senate when the parliament was prorogued prior to the 1996 election.So, the Labor Party introduced the legislation. It wanted to clarify and improve the rule‐making process. The chairman of the House of Representatives committee, encouraged very strongly by the member for Tangney, picked up this piece of legislation. We dealt with it as a committee and made a number of very important suggestions, some of which were adopted by the government of the day. Unfortunately in some ways, that legislation lapsed because of the elections. That has given the person who was the driving force in looking at these issues the opportunity now, as Attorney‐General, to come forward and put his own blush, his own colour, his own life into this legislation. I think that is a wonderful turn of events as far as this legislation is concerned.

Whilst, as the previous speaker said, it is a tentative step, few people in Australia would have considered, with the detail and discernment that the member for Tangney has, the need for reform of legislative instruments. Now we have come up with a solution that I think is going to greatly improve the processes of regulation making and legislative instruments in Australia. There will be clearer definitions of regulation-making powers and a greater clarity to everything that governments will be doing.

The Attorney‐General can be excused for trumpeting, in the handouts, the main benefits of this legislation. What he is saying is that it is going to improve public access to all delegated legislation through an electronic register of all legislative instruments. That alone will be a fabulous thing. It will allow people to actually know the rules they are working on, whether it be on building sites under Commonwealth law, whether it be on food regulations or whether it be on importations. In the Customs area alone, this is a far-sighted decision.

His second point of favour for this legislation is the mandatory consultation before legislative instruments affecting business are made. This was one of the platforms of the coalition before we went to the election. We said that we needed to simplify the rules and laws for small business. Nobody would think that a piece of dry legislation like this would be one of the very important parts of that process, but it is. The Attorney‐General has picked it up and he has enunciated this factor as being one of the most important aspects of the need for us in this country to have a law covering legislative instruments.

Mr Williams, the Attorney‐General, has been able to write the consultation process into the legislation. That is very important because unless those who are affected by rules are consulted we get all sorts of anomalies and unworkable situations, and even the circumstance from time to time where the unscrupulous can take advantage of oversights. We need to have this consultation and I think that is excellent.

With respect to measures to improve drafting quality, that is an endless process and it is one that all members of parliament would endorse anyway. I think enhanced parliamentary scrutiny is something that the committee wanted and I know the member for Banks felt that improved scrutiny was needed. That original report was such a good report. There was complete consultation and there was also consensus.

The provision for a five‐year sunsetting of legislative instruments is something that the Labor Party was not able to agree to but Mr Williams, as the new Attorney, has brought that through. I am pleased with the amendments that are here today which change the five‐year sunset to some extent. The reason that that five‐year sunset clause had to be changed is really obvious. For example, very significant protocols, such as quarantine protocols may take, as members would know, three to five years to develop. There are some people involved in the chicken industry debate later this day who would hope that those protocols are never established, and it will take us a million years to settle those protocols. Great care is needed to settle protocols.

A 15‐year sunset provision for exporting industries, particularly where they affect quarantine processes, is needed. These things take a long time to examine. You can draw on expert information from around the world—the scientific process undertaken, the decisions and the debate and, of course, consultation, can take five years. Therefore, a five-year process of establishing a protocol for the reasons of quarantine well justifies a 15‐year sunset clause.

I think this is a great piece of legislation. It moves in the direction that I think every member of the committee wanted us to move and I think that most members of the parliament would appreciate it. If they were aware of the brilliant work that was done by that committee, they would be applauding the members of it. Unfortunately, such is the nature of this place that our colleagues do not always appreciate the excellent work that we do.

I conclude by pointing out that in 1990 there were about 1,424 decisions of a legislative type. They were not passed through the parliament. They were usually placed on the table and if anybody objected they were dealt with. But it was not possible to amend; it was only possible to accept or reject those instruments. They used to just flick through the House and nobody was any the wiser. A former senior officer of the Attorney‐General's Department drew attention to this problem of the large amount of secondary legislation. Professor Curtis, in evidence to the committee, said that this is in contrast to the earlier practices of using regulations by the Governor‐General as the basic form of delegated legislation. We have departed from that process in many instances rather than only in special circumstances.

Professor Curtis has also asserted that the many forms of delegated legislation that now take place means that the convenience of the bureaucracy is met and that that has been allowed to transcend the convenience of the public. That is the reason for this legislation. I applaud the Attorney‐General. I thank the chamber and I look forward to hearing the comments of the former chairman of the House of Representatives legal and constitutional affairs committee.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Melham, Daryl, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —As I think has already been outlined in the debate, the Legislative Instruments Bill 1996 has had a somewhat tortuous path. Firstly, the intervention of the election earlier this year has again seen the same players wearing different hats.

SPEECH.PARA: At the outset, I want to commend the officers from the Attorney‐General's Department who have maintained a consistent carriage in relation to this bill. This is not one of those bills that one could describe as a sexy bill—one that members of the public get excited about—but it really is integral to the function of our parliamentary democracy. I do not think that people really understand that, and it needs to be pointed out.

The purpose of this bill is to reform the Commonwealth's procedures for making, scrutinising, publishing, amending and repealing subordinate legislation. The bill consolidates into one act existing procedural requirements found in the Acts Interpretation Act 1901 and the Statutory Rules Publication Act 1903. The measures are aimed at allowing greater scrutiny of, and public access to, delegated legislation. That is important for decision makers. It is important for those who are interested in what decisions are made and for those who are drafting decisions. It is important for the public.

It was the subject of a parliamentary committee, not only in the Senate, but also in the House of Representatives, which I chaired. It was notable, again, that that parliamentary committee produced a unanimous report. It had support across the parties, and it did not just toe the government line. It made a number of substantial recommendations that we felt would improve the bill. A number of those recommendations were taken up, and some were discarded. There have been some amendments in the current bill.

From the opposition's point of view, we have encouraged an expedited passage of this bill, and we will be expediting it through the House of Representatives. We will not be moving any amendments, but I do telegraph that the current shadow Attorney‐General does have some reservations and some matters that he wants to discuss with the government. That process, one hopes, will take place in the Senate.

He is concerned about retaining parliamentary review, as well as ADJR review. It was noted that the report of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs on the 1994 bill recommended that parliamentary review should be maintained. That is something that he will be taking up with current the Attorney‐General.

I am of the view that some of these concerns can be worked through because I think there is goodwill on all sides. Some of the concerns are just a matter of degree. In some instances it is six of one and half a dozen of the other; we are all trying to achieve the same result. The truth is that here we have complex legislation where everyone is trying to achieve the same objects.

There have been some compromises. I know, for instance, that the Attorney‐General's Department takes a more radical line in terms of scrutiny than other departments do. We have a fairly conservative PM&C, and there are other departments that, obviously, would like a more conservative line. There have been some compromises in relation to that.

The other matter that the shadow Attorney‐General has asked me to mention is that he is not keen on the changes allowing ADJR review of the consultation process. The view is that this process will be considerably more onerous than the one stage, post‐development consultation process required by the 1994 bill. The 1994 bill did not permit ADJR review of that process. The current shadow Attorney‐General's view is this consultation process may be too prescriptive.

The purpose of this provision is merely to indicate best practice, not to provide a means by which the making of legislative instruments could be frustrated. It is felt that, to this extent, the two‐stage process could be permitted as demonstrating a higher minimum standard. However, it would also provide organised lobbies with an enforceable right of consultation not afforded to the general community. It is also felt that ADJR review could be used by an organised lobby as a means to frustrate the making of legislative instruments. But, again, it is a matter of degree, and I am sure the discussions will take place with goodwill when the bill proceeds to the Senate.

There is one other matter I have been asked to mention. The current bill has an exemption: where the instrument is required in the interests of national security, no certification is required by the Attorney. My understanding from the shadow Attorney‐General is that he would prefer certification by the Attorney‐General if the instrument is required in the interests of national security. Those are the only matters that I wish to raise and I have done so in a general manner.

The point I want to make is that there is a new player. We are now in opposition. It is not a question of reversing our earlier support for the bill; it is just one of those transitional arrangements. That is, sadly, part of the tortuous passage of this bill. I think these proposals can be talked through when the matter goes to the Senate and I am sure that the government will have an open mind. We have the benefit now of a number of reports by parliamentary committees.

I just repeat what I said earlier—it has been a tortuous path. I know that we tried to get the previous bill finalised before the election and we were unsuccessful because, as I say, I think it was not sexy enough for some people to give it priority. That is a sad thing. I do commend the role of all the players, particularly those officers who have provided the support structure.

I know that my parliamentary committee was afforded invaluable assistance by the Attorney‐General's Department, with a seconded officer. The secretariat of the parliamentary committee was sensational in providing a support structure and guidance for us members of parliament who sometimes take for granted the excellent support structure we have. I certainly commend the main thrust of the bill to the parliament, with those reservations that I say are genuine ones and that I am sure can be worked through.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Smith, Tony, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to support the Legislative Instruments Bill 1996. It is particularly appropriate in my view that I refer to comments made by the Attorney‐General (Mr Williams) when he was in opposition and, as the member for Tangney, said in 1995:

SPEECH.PARA: The extensions of individual rights in relation to executive action affecting the individual have not been matched by any major reforms in the legislative process. Even those modest changes (public inquiries by the Senate committees into bills) have no counterpart in the making of delegated legislation where the interests of the citizen have increasingly been sacrificed to governmental and bureaucratic convenience. The volume of secondary legislation has grown, the variety of forms of it has multiplied, the impact of it has become more and more significant, and the ability of citizens to access it has lessened.

With respect, I fully endorse those comments. It is very encouraging to see this bill following on from, as has been pointed out by the member for Banks (Mr Melham) and others, a tortuous prehistory. There has been a determination by the Attorney to see this measure through.

This is a complex bill. As the member for Banks said, on its face it is not particularly attractive in a public sense, but in reality it effects a very important legislative task in the overall context of the plethora of legislation by way of statutory and legislative instruments. It is interesting to look at some comparison between the statutory rules and total instruments as at 1982‐83, standing at 703, and as at 1995, standing at 2,239. That is about a 300 per cent increase.

With all of that going on it is becoming more and more impossible—in my legal practice I noticed it, certainly at a state level—not only for the purposes of the public but also for the lawyers, in particular, to advise their clients properly because of the difficulty in interpreting some of these instruments and, furthermore, gauging their possible impact, as well as in some cases merely finding them.

I recall specifically having to advise a client in relation to a matter arising out of a possible negligence against the main roads department. It was very simple, when I started at the bar, to identify the person to be sued—it was simply the Commissioner for Main Roads, and had been for many years. All of that changed under the Goss government and there was a plethora of legislative instruments which led a practitioner on an enormously difficult task of trying to find who had replaced the Commissioner for Main Roads as the entity to be sued.

My particular example, as the member for Barton (Mr McClelland) mentioned, did end in some peril but luckily it was retrievable. Nonetheless, it required an application to the court because, when I had assured myself and had been advised by other members of my chambers that I had got the right entity, unfortunately we discovered that yet another entity had replaced that entity in a period of six weeks, without any sign of that being readily to be found. It led to an application to the court to correct the name. That is just one small example, but one of the largest complaints that occurred when I was in practice was the fact that in the last few years, in particular, the difficulty of accessing those sorts of instruments and advising on them has been becoming greater and greater.

In a broader sense, it would be well for the Commonwealth to look at providing a far better annotation service generally than it has hitherto provided in relation not only to instruments, perhaps, but also in particular to Commonwealth acts, because that is another such area. I will not stray into that territory during this debate because it could occupy me for a rather lengthy period.

I want to draw the attention of the Main Committee to one particular matter that perhaps I am being overcautious about. Clause 28(1)(iii) speaks of circumstances in which compliance with sections 20 to 25 is not required. That relates to the particular area that interested me, where it says that the instrument:

. . . merely meets an obligation of the Commonwealth under an international agreement by repeating or adopting the terms of all or part of an instrument for which the agreement provides or to which the agreement makes reference . . .

I do wonder why that particular exception was put in there. As a member of the treaties committee, and it is a very active committee, I am interested to know what the rationale was for putting that there, or perhaps it is merely a matter that ought not to really excite my interest because it is purely an administrative or a reflection type of measure, rather than an adoption of any sort of adventurous, if you like, means of avoiding clauses 20 to 25.

I also want to mention the rules of court area. I note that clause 7 provides that the rules of court are not legislative instruments. I understand that the rationale behind that is that the independence of the judiciary may be compromised if executive government rules regarding the making of subordinate legislation were imposed on the courts. However, I caution a little on that particular area, without wishing to transgress or trespass upon the essential import of that clause. From time to time rules of court are promulgated and they follow, generally speaking, discussions between committees of the Bar Association and the Chief Justice or other judges who have been authorised to involve themselves in those discussions. At times, I have seen rules of court promulgated that I have wondered about in terms of their public effect, and I think there is a case for saying that there should be a mechanism—and there may well be—by which the executive and the parliament as well could have some role, be it through a committee recommendation or something of that nature, whereby if at least a relevant standing committee could look at a proposed rule of court it may be that there would be a wider community input than the narrow one now, without at all trespassing upon or compromising the independence of the judiciary.

I am very pleased, however, to see the register and the fact that again that provides a very real public and open element to this particular area. The bill will also have an impact, in my view, in reducing compliance costs incurred by business and others subject to government regulation. The bill has a very important function to serve, as has been indicated, but it will not be one that will be readily greeted with adulation by most of my constituents. In reality, when problems arise with some of these instruments it is immediately a matter that is sheeted home to us as legislators if we are not prepared to provide adequate safeguards when these instruments come into effect.

Overall, I am very heartened by this measure. As a new member, I am pleased to see that these matters are being addressed. They have been difficult in their embryonic stages and in bringing them to fruition, but we have got there, in my view. I wholeheartedly endorse this bill, with the fairly minor reservations I have mentioned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Rocher, Allan, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Legislative Instruments Bill 1996, which was introduced by the Attorney‐General (Mr Williams) on 26 June, sets out a regime for determining drafting standards and procedures for the making, registration, publication, scrutiny and sunsetting of delegated legislation. The bill defines the term `legislative instrument', specifically excludes particular instruments and provides a method by which an Attorney‐General's certificate can be issued to resolve doubt about whether the application of the definition is unclear.

SPEECH.PARA: The coalition announced in its small business policy, prior to the last election, that it was committed to strengthening the legislative instruments bill which was introduced by the former Labor government. As such, the Legislative Instruments Bill 1996 relates very much to the hopes and aspirations advocated by the coalition.

The bill includes several features to which I want to draw attention, such as the development and maintenance of an electronic register of all delegated legislation, to which the public will have access; mandatory consultation before legislative instruments affecting business are made; measures to improve drafting quality; enhanced parliamentary scrutiny; and provisions for five‐year sunsetting of legislative instruments to ensure continued relevance. In particular, the inclusion of a five‐year sunsetting of new regulations, which was promised in the coalition's small business policy, is most welcome and highly commendable.

The bill, in my opinion, represents a great leap forward in the present situation, and of course I support it wholeheartedly. My own reservation—like the previous speaker's, but in a different direction—is that it does not go far enough. There are currently 209 pages of regulations in force under the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936. It is beneficial for small business in particular that these regulations face review every five years. But they were only a fraction of the real level of regulation faced by all taxpayers.

Small business—as you are only too well aware, Mr Deputy Speaker—is burdened with over 3,800 pages of income tax law and some 970 income tax rulings. The tax acts themselves are riddled with discretionary power in the hands of the Commissioner of Taxation which, in the ordinary course of his business, he delegates throughout the Australian Taxation Office. In addition, there are over 1,600 additional pages of tax laws, 397 sales tax rulings, and other tax rulings and determinations.

Although these additional rulings and determinations are not regulations in the strictest sense, they seem to me, in many if not all cases, to serve exactly the same purpose. They clarify the law, in other words. The purpose of them is not only to clarify the law, but also to give the Australian Taxation Office's opinion on what the law means and how certain tax matters will be treated. There are actually two types of rulings: public and private. Public rulings may apply generally to all taxpayers, while private rulings relate to specific tax matters brought to the attention of the ATO by a single or individual taxpayer.

BREAK.PARA: Public rulings and determinations should be, in my humble submission, Mr Deputy Speaker, subject to the same scrutiny as regulations and hence the source of my remarks and concern. Although not law or delegated legislation in a stricter sense, the ATO applies these rulings as if they were law. Where an individual disagrees with a ruling by the ATO, the only recourse is to challenge it in the courts on the ground that it is inconsistent or contrary to the relevant tax act. If the ATO holds its rulings and determinations up as law, then they should be subject to the same degree of scrutiny to which regulations are subject. They should be treated as regulations, face disapproval by either house of parliament and have five‐year sunset clauses, entirely consistent with the legislation before the committee.

The Joint Committee of Public Accounts in its report no. 326, handed down in November 1993, recommended amongst other things that all public tax rulings should go through a formal approval process. To avoid uncertainty about whether a ruling is private or public, all public rulings should be gazetted. Parliament should have a supervisory role and there should be the creation of a publicly available register consolidating all determinations in public and private rulings as well.

In those ways, it is not dissimilar to what the government sets out to do with this legislation. As Michael Dirkis wrote in the International Bureau of Fiscal Documentation's publication called Bulletin, the Joint Committee, and I quote:
recommended that all public rulings should be tabled in the parliament within five days of gazettal, allowing the parliament to evaluate and analyse them and respond to unsatisfactory rulings.

It is the responsibility of the parliament to make the laws of this land. All public rulings and determinations should be subjected to parliamentary scrutiny to ensure that they comply with the parliament's will and its interpretation of the meaning of how its laws should be interpreted and applied.

The Commissioner of Taxation should not have, in other words, the unfettered right to draft tax rules. In a democratic state, binding rules of a tax nature should only be established with the approval of the parliament or, at the very least, a right to disallow. `No taxation without representation' is enshrined by way of principle in Anglo‐Saxon nations, as it is in the United States. Charles I lost his head over this very issue, Mr Deputy Speaker, when he tried to raise taxes without the approval of the parliament and, of course, George III lost the American colonies over the issue.

While the tax commissioner is not at risk of losing his head over this and neither are any ministers, he and they certainly deserved to lose any ability to bypass this accountability to the parliament. Let us be frank—the commissioner and the Australian Taxation Office have been overzealous on many occasions.

The ability of the parliament to disallow tax rulings is also part of a wider need to protect our citizens against the arbitrary power of the government and its agencies. For too long, power has been usurped by the executive at the expense of the parliament. This is part of a wider democratic deficit. Sir Ninian Stephen used that term to describe the use of international treaties to transfer power from national to supranational bodies.

TALK.START.PARA: —They just had a big win last week in the High Court.

—Yes, indeed. This term can be just as appropriately used to describe the executive's increasing willingness to impose rights and responsibilities on Australian citizens without parliament's prior knowledge or consent. This is a development which should be wound back, and tax rulings are a good place to begin. This legislation might be a vehicle for doing just that—by subsequent amendment, of course.

BREAK.PARA: The number of determinations and tax rulings which are currently being issued at the tax commissioner's discretion is increasing every day, as we all know only too well. It is no surprise then that Australia's tax system is amongst the most complex and expensive in the Western world to comply with, with all its implications for small business; which complexity and cost of compliance this bill is but a small part of trying to address.

The complexity simply adds, in a way which is almost unique in the world, to the cost of doing business, and it is a deterrent to the growth of employment. It is a serious obstacle to establishing a small business. Compliance costs are absolutely regressive, and all affect small taxpayers, particularly unincorporated self‐employed business men and women, to a much larger extent than perhaps they affect larger firms.

The Australian Taxation Office continues to issue tax rulings in a manner which runs contrary to the philosophy of the Howard government of reducing regulations on small business. The tax commissioner's discretionary powers are adding to both the complexity of our tax laws and the burgeoning costs of compliance. The present federal government promised the small‐business community that it would slash, by some 50 per cent in its first term, the amount of government generated paper work that small business had to deal with.

So far, the Minister for Small Business and Consumer Affairs (Mr Prosser) has established the Small Business Deregulation Task Force, the National Small Business Summit, the Micro‐business Consultative Group and the Office of Small Business. It is only early days, but it is unfortunate that that particular minister is already backtracking from the coalition's commitments by creating a bureaucratic structure to handle promptly that which it should have had the capacity to initiate from within its own ranks.

TALK.START.PARA: —How?

—More committees and endless consultations are no substitute for general reform. One would have thought that, after 13 years in opposition and all the waffle—I was part of it—you would know what to do when you got in, after those 13 years. What you have done is embark on a formula for delay. It is time that the government addressed the real issues, rather than paying lip‐service to the needs of small business. It is the same lip‐service that we saw so much of under the previous government. The fringe benefits tax has compliance costs which are at least six times higher than those in New Zealand. The wholesale sales tax ranges from zero per cent to 200 per cent, in the case of some alcoholic beverages, and consequently is a nightmare to administer. The Building Owners and Managers Association, in its submission to the Productivity Commission's review of micro‐economic reform stated:

BREAK.PARA: The cost of complying with the Australian taxation system is a major obstacle to earning assessable income and investment. In the recent past, new legislation and rulings have had little regard for the compliance burden placed on business. Reducing the costs of compliance must be the first priority of micro‐economic reform.

As long as we have a tax office which is more interested in wringing every single dollar out of business and in drafting what is sometimes the most ludicrous and difficult legislation or set of tax rulings to comply with, we will continue to face high compliance costs.

We have one of the most archaic tax systems in the Western world and, of course, along with others, I join in claiming that a complete review of tax policy is required. The Howard government needs to get serious about getting government paperwork and impediments off the back of the proprietors of small businesses. Small businesses, as we know, offer the best opportunity to reduce the unemployment level in this country. The Productivity Commission's July 1996 Industry brief stated:

Small firms continue to drive employment growth in Australia. The latest estimates reveal that the small business workforce rose by 6.4 percent or 225,000 jobs in 1994‐95. This was well above the 3.9 percent employment growth in the economy as a whole over the same period. This growth continues a long‐term trend, with small businesses accounting for almost all the net 1.2 million new jobs in Australia over the last decade. Small firms now employ just under half of all Australian workers. Notably, between 1985‐86 and 1994-95, small businesses increased their share of employment in all sectors and now account for 45 percent or more of employment in all industries apart from mining and community services.

TALK.START.PARA: —I raise a point of order. Mr Deputy Speaker, this is a very fine appropriation speech but I do not think it has got anything at all to do with this bill.

—I have been listening very closely to the Member for Curtin. Whilst some of the areas that he touched on were fairly broad, I think the principles of his speech have been adhered to and are contained in the bill. There is no point of order.
—Thank you. We need to reduce the costs of compliance with all regulations for small business, as well as reducing other unnecessary impediments faced by the small business sector.

BREAK.PARA: As I said earlier, I support this legislation. Delegated legislation needs to be reviewed on a regular and ongoing basis, and the processes enabling review also need to be easily accessible to the public. If the coalition wants to get serious about tackling red tape, it needs also to look at other matters, such as tax rulings and determinations.
The coalition's small business policy stated:

It has been, since 1983, an era of wasted opportunities and of shameless Labor government inaction on issues of paramount importance to the small business sector. The Labor government condones the swamping of small business under an unnecessary and continuous paper war. Labor's legacy to small business has been the proliferation of red tape and regulation, tax complexity and draconian industrial relations policy. Frustration, desperation and confusion add to the overall cost of lost management focus, detracting from the essential task of developing core business initiatives.

I, along with—more importantly, probably—many in the business community, am monitoring and will continue to monitor the reforms of the coalition government in meeting its election commitments to small business.

A good start would be to reduce the complexity of the tax system, including public tax rulings and determinations made by the Commissioner of Taxation within the scope of this legislation. It would be a good start. If jobs and economic growth are going to be maximised, we need to give small business the ability to focus on important operational matters, not red tape.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Williams, Daryl, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply—It is pleasing to see that the Legislative Instruments Bill 1996 has support across the chamber. It will provide an enhanced basis for parliamentary scrutiny of legislative instruments. It will, as a number of speakers have mentioned, return some role and responsibility to parliament from the executive in the making of delegated legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: It also brings into parliamentary view a considerable increase in the volume of material that will need to be considered in parliament. That, in itself, is likely to create other problems which will need to be addressed in the appropriate way. I think appropriate consideration needs to be given to the role of the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances. That has been a very important committee over the years. I believe that, with the passage of this legislation, it will become a bulwark for the community's interests.

The two houses, and the House of Representatives in particular, also have important roles in the scrutiny of instruments under the bill and that also will be a procedural matter to be looked at in the future. The willingness of the executive to allow motions for disallowance to be given appropriate debate will be a matter that will have to be considered by those controlling parliamentary business. It will also be a matter for the hard-pressed Senate in its dealing with its business.

Before turning to comment on some of the contributions made by members in debate, I join with others in commending a number of bodies who have been instrumental in the bill's reaching this stage and who have made important contributions.

First, I think it should be mentioned that the origin of the bill was a report of the Administrative Review Council going back to 1992. The chair of the committee at that time, Professor Cheryl Saunders, maintained an interest—although she subsequently ceased to be chair—and was a witness before the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs in its consideration of the bill. I join with the member for Banks (Mr Melham) in commending the continued work of the officers of the Attorney‐General's Department who have laboured mightily over this piece of legislation. There are two Senate committees that have considered the bill—the Senate Standing Committee on Regulations and Ordinances and the Senate Scrutiny of Bills Committee. They have both delivered reports. Probably the most important report, however, is the one that is being mentioned most frequently in debate here—that of the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs. That committee reported in September 1995 on the 1994 bill. I join with the member for Mitchell (Mr Cadman) in commending the member for Banks on his chairmanship of that committee, the committee members for their work and, I might add, the witnesses who appeared before it. I can recall some very valuable contributions made by experts which have been taken up in the report and are now reflected in the bill.

It will be necessary, I think, for virtually all arms of government to give serious consideration to the implications of this bill for the administration of the department. In addition, it will be necessary for each of the relevant Houses and for a number of committees to consider how the implications of this bill will be dealt with.

I thank all the members who have spoken on this bill; each has supported the bill. A number have made some comments or criticisms, some more detailed than others. The member for Barton (Mr McClelland) raised the issue—it was probably a fairly obvious one—of why the consultation requirement is limited to business. I think this is a matter that has been addressed at considerable length in the deliberations that have preceded the debate in this House. There is very good reason for extension of the provisions of the bill to all aspects of government.

There is, recognisably, resistance in the public service to the introduction of such new requirements holus-bolus. The decision was taken fairly early on by the previous government that, as a first step, the act should extend its consultation requirements to legislation affecting business. While there are strong arguments for the view that it should apply to all legislation, we have maintained that decision and have strengthened the resolution that this bill should in due course be seen as inevitably applying to all departments and all aspects of government involved in the making of delegated legislation. The immediate impact on those areas affecting business will, I think, convince the other departments of the desirability of the consultation process for other forms of legislation.

The member for Banks raised three points reflecting what he foreshadowed would be raised by the shadow Attorney‐General, Senator Bolkus, in debate in the Senate. It is a matter of some regret to me that the debate on those issues in this House is not full, in order for me to address those matters of concern.

The first point mentioned was the Attorney‐General's certificate. I presume, given what the member for Banks was saying, that the shadow Attorney‐General has in mind the certificate, under clause 8 of the bill, as to whether a proposed instrument is a legislative instrument or not. There has been a lot of debate, particularly in the House of Representatives committee, as to the manner in which the certificate should be dealt with and, in fact, whether there should be a certificate at all.

The background to it is that it was felt, in the formulation of the bill, that many departments would have difficulty in determining whether an instrument was of a legislative character or not. In order to assist departments faced with that sort of decision, it was felt that some mechanism for determination ought to be introduced. The mechanism chosen was a certificate by the Attorney‐General as to whether an instrument was legislative or not in character. The question then arose as to how that should be reviewed or how that should be reviewable. A lot of debate went on as to whether that was a decision which should be subject to parliamentary disallowance or should be subject to judicial review. I think the initial view of the House of Representatives committee was that it should be subject to both.

I can recall some very interesting debate as to the nature of the decision of the Attorney‐General and whether that, in itself, would be a legislative act. It involved authorities such as Professor Stan Hotop, Professor Dennis Pearce and Professor Cheryl Saunders. I think, in the end, the committee ended up somewhat confused as to what the outcome should be. The view I formed—after reflecting considerably and then abandoning all the advice—was that the Attorney‐General's certificate should be seen simply for what it is: it is a legal opinion as to whether an instrument is legislative in character or not. It is, in effect, legal advice.

Legal opinions, in my view, are not appropriate for parliamentary review. You cannot invite parliament to disallow an opinion because, in order to reach that opinion, it is really going to have to form a legal opinion itself. While it does that frequently, that is not an appropriate function for a corporate body such as the House or a committee of the House. It is a function that is undertaken with some difficulty.

The Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act method of review is a process designed specifically to determine legal questions. On that basis, it seems to me that the Attorney‐General's certificate is very appropriately reviewable by the Federal Court on an ADJR application. It is on that basis that the bill now reflects that point of view: parliamentary disallowance is not provided for and ADJR review is contemplated.

The second point raised by the member for Banks concerned the ADJR implications of the consultation process. There are a number of decisions of an administrative character to be made in the course of the consultation process, which have the potential to be brought under review under the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act.

It is easy to assert that this could be used for stonewalling by a lobby group. But I think, on reflection, it is more of a floodgates argument than one with real meat. There are many situations where a determined opponent can bring an ADJR application for review of an administrative decision. But, in the end, it is a matter that can be dealt with readily and quickly if it is without merit. If it is not without merit, then it is appropriate for it to be determined by the Federal Court.

For my part, I offer some scepticism to the suggestion that there will be blocking by lobby groups, where legislative instrument proposals are put forward. I recognise that it is certainly a possibility, but ADJR applications are legal proceedings in superior courts: they are not lightly brought and they are not lightly maintained and, in addition, they are quite expensive. I suggest that it would be appropriate for the ADJR freedom to be continued. In the review process that is contemplated within the three years of operation of the bill, that particular point can be examined.

The next point raised by the member for Banks on behalf of the shadow Attorney‐General, Senator Bolkus, related to the exemption from consultation of instruments required because of an issue of national security. The suggestion is made that there should be a certificate by the Attorney‐General. I really question whether that is likely to have any practical effect. The practical situation is that the issue of national security is likely to emanate from Foreign Affairs, Defence or perhaps even agencies within the Attorney‐General's portfolio. It is an issue that is of some significance and will obviously have to be the subject of a determination.

In the ordinary course of events, under this piece of legislation, that determination would probably be made by either the Attorney‐General or a delegate of the Attorney‐General. It would be subject to judicial review under section 29 and, therefore, the effect of having a certificate of the Attorney‐General, which would be subject to judicial review, is already there. I really wonder whether there is any substance in the point, but perhaps we will have to wait until the shadow Attorney‐General details his argument in order for us to understand exactly what it is.

The member for Dickson (Mr Tony Smith) referred to the exemption from consultations for certain instruments made in consequence of obligations of the Commonwealth under an international agreement—section 28(1)(3). This provides that the rule maker is not required to comply with the consultation provisions, if the rule maker is satisfied that the instrument merely meets an obligation of the Commonwealth under an international agreement by repeating or adopting the terms of all or part of an instrument for which the agreement provides, or to which the agreement makes reference.

The background to this goes back to the House of Representatives committee report. It considered the provision in the 1994 bill, which was in different terms. In the 1994 bill, it was contemplated that consultation would not be necessary where an obligation is imposed on the Commonwealth under an international agreement to make a legislative instrument. It was a much broader provision, and the committee was opposed to one in those terms.

Since the committee has reported, however, there have been significant reforms effected by the coalition government to the treaty‐making processes, and there are significant mechanisms already in place for public consultation in relation to the entry into treaties. We have made provision for a treaties council, which will involve the states and territories and bodies making representations to them. We have made provision for the joint parliamentary treaties committee, which can review proposed international instruments, and for the tabling of proposed international instruments 15 days before they become binding on Australia.

In the light of that, there is significant opportunity for public consultation in relation to the entry into the obligation. That is not to say that that consultation will be the same as consultation in relation to a proposed regulation that would implement the international obligation. But there is some overlap in what would be dealt with in the two consultation processes. All that is set out in the proposed section 28 to be exempted is an instrument that merely repeats or adopts verbatim, in effect, the terms of the agreement in question. It is a very narrow exemption, and I think that it meets the requirement.

I note that the member for Curtin (Mr Rocher) also raised the issue of treaty obligations in his speech. I would suggest that the points he made would be met by the same arguments that I have sought to make to the point made by the member for Dickson.

The member for Dickson also mentioned the rules of court. Again, the rules of court were the subject of some considerable debate before the House of Representatives committee. There was an argument raised whether it constituted an intrusion on judicial independence for the parliament to be involved in the making of rules of court. That argument, I think, was rightly rejected.

But it is not true to suggest that rules of court are exempt. Under schedule 4, there are fairly extensive provisions under the Industrial Relations Act amending the statutes relating to the Family Court and the Federal Court. These will have the effect of requiring consultation to be modified to some extent, but, in general terms, it will be of the same nature as applies to other regulations. In our submission that is appropriately covered.

The member for Curtin has made a speech cogently arguing that public and private rulings, which were exempt from the consultation process under schedule 1 of the act, should be covered. That is an argument that was aired—

TALK.START.PARA: —Public, only public.

—The member for Curtin corrects me. He is concerned only with public rulings. That is a matter which was aired at some length also in the House of Representatives committee. I would accept that there is considerable strength in the arguments he puts. The difficulty is, I think, that those rulings are increasingly voluminous and increasing in number. (Extension of time granted) I am indebted to the Main Committee. The huge volume and the very specialist nature of the various rulings raise special considerations. There is no doubt that there is a strong case for a requirement of public consultation. It is one that I would not attempt to argue against. Equally, I would not attempt to argue against the impact of the production of the number of rulings and their length, and the content of those rulings on small business, as well as big business and individuals.

SPEECH.PARA: However, in our desire to ensure that the Legislative Instruments Bill gets through quickly, we decided that it was appropriate to give further consideration to how the tax rulings might be dealt with. We have in contemplation, as was in contemplation by the previous government, a review of the operation of the bill within a three‐year period and, in the course of that time, we hope we can deal with tax rulings.

There is a further problem which should be mentioned in relation to tax rulings. The need for such a huge number of tax rulings really arises out of the nature of the Income Tax Assessment Act and the related legislation itself. While one cannot be confident that the simplification writing program is likely to have major impact in the short term, it ought to have some impact which would obviate a need for the sorts of rulings that are required in the detailed provisions that exist in the present bill. That also is a matter that needs to be carefully considered in this context.

BREAK.PARA: The Member for Curtin can rest assured that as far as I and the government are concerned we are anxious to fulfil the coalition policy to ensure that the regulations that apply to business are reduced in effect, in cost and in delay. The reform of the tax rulings will be seen as an important part of that, in due course.

I think I have dealt with each of the issues raised by the speakers, Mr Deputy Speaker. It may not be to the satisfaction of all the speakers; however, that is the answer that they will receive from me for the time being. I commend the bill to the House. I thank all those who spoke and supported the bill. I thank again all those who were involved in its genesis.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
