SPEECH.SPEAKER: Melham, Daryl, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker. The Bankruptcy Legislation Amendment Bill has some history. I think that is true of a number of bills. That is why I think it is easy to mix it up because the same sorts of principles apply.

SPEECH.PARA: Most of the legislation that we are dealing with does have cross‐party support. This demonstrates to the public that a lot of the clips they see on television are not necessarily the reality. All they see are politicians haggling, arguing and engaging in dissent. The truth is that the overwhelming majority of legislation that passes through this House is debated in a genuine spirit of goodwill and cross‐party support, which is generally achieved on a lot of legislation—and the Bankruptcy Legislation Amendment Bill is one case in point.

It was introduced on 8 March 1995 by the Labor government as the Bankruptcy Legislation Amendment Bill of 1995. On 28 June 1995, the bill was referred to the Senate Legal and Constitutional Legislation Committee for inquiry and report. That committee recommended five amendments to the bill. It is interesting to note that there was a dissenting report by senators Abetz, Ellison and O'Chee. I mention that because that minority report has been repudiated not only by the previous Labor government but also by the current government, as it should be. I think that needs to be pointed out.

I think those three senators are starting to develop a bit of a reputation as the `three amigos'. If they continue, their reputation will probably move on to become the `three stooges'. I am not saying that they are not genuinely motivated, but the reality is that I think their comments are really without substance in this instance.

What needs to be pointed out here is that because their dissenting report was not accepted in the last parliament, they fired it off to the Senate legislation committee. Basically, the reservations that we have, not necessarily with the bill, were outlined in the minority report by Senator Bolkus and Senator McKiernan. I think it is worth quoting from their report in terms of some reservations that we have. It is the opposition's view that:
The Attorney‐General should restore adequate funding to the Insolvency and Trustee Service of Australia.

The minority report pointed out that they were in agreement with the Credit Union Services Corporation of Australia who expressed their concern about the adequacy of funding for the Insolvency and Trustee Service Australia—ITSA. Senators Bolkus and McKiernan noted that:
. . . the Attorney‐General pre‐empted a response to this concern by agreeing to cuts totalling $434,000 over the next four years.
The other concern of Senators Bolkus and McKiernan, which is an opposition concern, is:

. . . the decision of the Government to increase the rate of cost recovery for ITSA. These measures will raise an additional $22 million over 4 years. The minority believes that this measure is regressive. It calls upon the victims of bankruptcy, creditors, to pay more for services that they would otherwise wish not to require. This measure will particularly impact on small business and make them even more reluctant to engage in bankruptcy proceedings leaving them to carry a greater share of the cost to the community from bankruptcy.
Apart from those reservations, the opposition is in general agreement with this bill.

I also want to reiterate that I for one appreciate the diligence of the current Attorney‐General and Minister for Justice (Mr Williams). I appreciate the way he regularly attends the Main Committee, listens to the debate and offers constructive suggestions in reply. I think that is treating the Main Committee with the respect with which it should be treated. Too often—and I think this is true of the former government as well—parliamentary secretaries were delegated. I do not want to take away from parliamentary secretaries, but I do have an old‐fashioned view that if a minister has carriage of a particular bill, it is a matter of courtesy to the House and the Main Committee that the minister, if at all possible, should be present throughout the debate and should respond. I think that is something that is certainly the hallmark of this Attorney‐General and I commend him for it. I know he has the support across the chamber for the civility and courtesy that he has been extending to the House.

We do not agree on everything and we are not going to agree on everything. That is not the nature of the business we are in. But we do accept that we have different views. I think that we are all on the same path. We might take different paths at times but it ends up with, I think, better legislation. I wanted to put that on the record. I do not think it can be said often enough.

We believe in the parliamentary process, the importance of parliament and the role of backbenchers having access to and input into legislation and being listened to by a minister. There is nothing more disconcerting, after all that effort which is put in by members of the back bench—and they can have an input—than to have that effort ignored. It is good to have a minister present. I have seen instances where suggestions have been taken up at a later stage. I commend the minister for that practice and, again, say that the opposition has no problem with supporting the bill. We, in effect, started it, but this government will finish it for us.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Zammit, Paul, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I will be very brief. As a former businessman who for 13 years ran my own business and for eight years before that ran someone else's business, I can say to you that I have a very great interest in the changes that are being brought forward in this bill.

SPEECH.PARA: I was a bit concerned at the remarks of the honourable member for Banks (Mr Melham) who said that he thought this would be an impost on business. I could not disagree with him more. This will mean a tremendous assistance for business, and small business, in general. I found the matter of bankruptcy, in regards to the people that I traded with when I was running someone else's company or when I was running my own company, one of the most frustrating and difficult things to try to work out.

This legislative change will mean that there will be a one‐stop shop. There will not be the differences that currently occur between two separate federal bodies, each doing virtually the same thing, and people not knowing which one to go to or which one to refer to. It will also mean that people who are facing financial difficulties will be able to get some advice and will be able to know what is the best procedure for them to adopt to try to resolve the matter.

I would like to say that probably the most important thing I see in this bill is the resolution of the question of the transfer of funds. At present, people who would normally be liable can go to a court and say that they have nothing when, in fact, they do. I felt considerable anger and frustration when I had my own business, when the directors of one of the companies I was dealing with told me that they just could not pay any more and that they had to declare themselves bankrupt. That is exactly what happened.

A week or so later, I was with my family for a short holiday up at Terrigal. I saw one of the directors, a woman, with her husband and their children, staying at Terrigal in a very up‐market hotel, a hotel that I certainly could not afford to stay at. I felt extremely angry that they were able to manipulate the system in such a way that they were not only able to get away with not paying what was owed to me, but they were also able to flaunt that in such a way that made me, and a lot of my friends in business, very angry.

There is a degree of retrospectivity in this, and there is no doubt that it is part of it. I have always been against the concept of retrospectivity. But, there are some steps that could be taken retrospectively by those who could be facing financial difficulties and, as a result, it is absolutely necessary to try to balance these rorts that are being pulled by people who, frankly, are just not worth supporting in any way, shape or form. I think that this will mean that notice will be given that they cannot continue to act in the way that they have acted.

I note that the honourable member for Banks says that the opposition will be supporting the bill. I would like to also commend the Attorney‐General (Mr Williams) on the detail in which he has presented the bill and the very strong manner in which he proposed this and supported it in our party room.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Johnston, Ricky, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak in the Main Committee today on the Bankruptcy Legislation Amendment Bill. The purpose of this bill is to assist in the government's commitment to modernising the law on personal insolvency by amending the Bankruptcy Act 1966 and the Administrative Decisions (Judicial Review) Act 1977.

SPEECH.PARA: This bill contains a key provision on something I feel fairly strongly about; that is, the tightening of the provisions dealing with those who divest themselves of property to third parties when they are facing bankruptcy.

The bill also contains many other significant amendments. The proposed amendments relate to four main areas. Firstly, these proposed amendments will make amendments to part 9 of the act, introducing a new form of insolvency arrangements, to be called `debt agreements', for low income debtors. This will allow registered trustees to process debt agreement proposals and to streamline procedures for accepting debt agreement proposals. It will also correct a drafting error in the formula for calculating the income threshold for debt agreement proposals.

BREAK.PARA: Secondly, item 356, which proposed section 204A, is omitted as a consequence of the High Court decision in the Brandy v. Human Rights and Equal Opportunity Commission case, with consequential amendments resulting from this change. These changes restore the current position regarding the effect of a special resolution of creditors where they have resolved that a person become a bankrupt. The proposed amendment states that following a creditor's resolution a debtor must present a debtor's petition or, if the debtor does not present a petition, a creditor must apply to the court for a subsequent order.

Thirdly, a minor amendment to sections 189A and 189B is proposed, to require reports to be provided to creditors following the giving of an authority under section 188 of the act. Lastly, it is also proposed that these amendments give legislative effect to the abolition of the Federal Court of Bankruptcy.

The Bankruptcy Legislation Amendment Bill proposes a wide range of very important reforms to the Bankruptcy Act. These reforms are eagerly awaited by personal insolvency practitioners, and they will assist the community as a whole by introducing a more effective regime in this area. They will, in addition, provide for cheaper and simpler processes and a new alternative to bankruptcy, while also clarifying the law in some areas.

The measures proposed in this bill will streamline procedures and processes for trustees by introducing a new form of insolvency arrangement. They will also tighten up former transaction avoidance provisions, bringing about a major improvement in bankruptcy administration. The proposal of a one‐stop shop whereby certain administrative functions are transferred from the Federal Court to the Insolvency and Trustee Service Australia will greatly assist persons contemplating bankruptcy in considering the options available to them. More importantly, debtors who voluntarily file for bankruptcy will have their cases dealt with more promptly and will need to file documents with only one agency. This will, in turn, reduce administrative costs.

This government is one which listens to the people. We understand and, indeed, appreciate the valuable contributions that can be made by insolvency professionals when determining how to best achieve improved, user‐friendly and less costly laws in this area. The ongoing establishment of a consultative forum, inviting key players from the insolvency sector to participate on a regular basis, will be of benefit to all.

For most people contemplating or filing for voluntary bankruptcy, the point in their lives when they experience such a moment is often associated with anxiety. This, in turn, affects the social and economic security of not only the bankrupts but also their families. The very last thing that one needs at such a time is complicated laws, and the amendments proposed in this bill will help to lessen the burden and the trauma.
Bill read a second time.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN ANIMAL HEALTH COUNCIL (LIVE‐STOCK INDUSTRIES) FUNDING BILL 1996Cognate bills:CATTLE EXPORT CHARGES AMENDMENT (AAHC) BILL 1996CATTLE TRANSACTION LEVY AMENDMENT (AAHC) BILL 1996LAYING CHICKEN LEVY AMENDMENT (AAHC) BILL 1996LIVE‐STOCK EXPORT CHARGE AMENDMENT (AAHC) BILL 1996LIVE‐STOCK SLAUGHTER LEVY AMENDMENT (AAHC) BILL 1996MEAT CHICKEN LEVY AMENDMENT (AAHC) BILL 1996PIG SLAUGHTER LEVY AMENDMENT (AAHC) BILL 1996

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 26 June, on motion by Mr Anderson:
That the bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Baldwin, Bob, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —This package of cognate livestock industry bills is a sound and progressive approach to provide funding to the Australian Animal Health Council. I believe this reform package is most relevant at this time when the fundamentals of free market economic philosophy come face to face and match up with the reality of exotic diseases and with the necessity to keep our agricultural sector clean and disease free. Our nation is the world's largest supplier of beef to export markets and is by far the dominant supplier of wool in international trade. Just last week, our burgeoning wine industry reported record exports and production levels.

SPEECH.PARA: According to the `mother' of the Australian Animal Health Council—EXANDIS, the Exotic Animal Disease Preparedness Consultative Council—in its final report before being subsumed into the AAHC in 1995, some 54 animal diseases were not currently present in Australia but could enter and threaten the livestock industry. Diseases such as the much dreaded foot‐andmouth, rinderpest, blue tongue, vesicular stomatitis, screw worm fly, African swine fever and hog cholera—or, as it is termed, classical swine fever—already pose great concern.

As the federal member whose electorate has the largest concentration of chicken growers across Australia, I also point out that the virulent newcastle disease—the poultry industry's own version of foot‐and‐mouth—has, and can quite easily again, wreak havoc on our nation's doorstep. Ask the Tasmanian Salmon Growers Association about the potential diseases—at least 23—presently not gracing our shores if importers of uncooked and unsmoked Canadian salmon get the thumbs up, and about the repercussions for the rest of the Australian livestock and agricultural industry as outlined in a feature article in the Fairfax publication, Sun‐Herald, on 8 September 1996. I seek leave to table that document and have it included in Hansard.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER (Mr Quick)

TALK.START.PARA: —It can be tabled by leave, but not incorporated.

INTERJECT.PARA: Leave granted.

TALK.START.PARA: —Directing funds from the relevant levying arrangements for each of those industries to the AAHC is a necessary cost impost to keep the walls high and strong to halt exotic disease in its tracks at the farm gate. Importantly, this legislation will allow the agricultural industry to meet its funding obligations to the council. The statement holds: tomorrow, the Prime Minister, John Howard, will be publicly bringing to life a bold pre‐election commitment that will set our agricultural sector apart—from being a mere food bowl of pickings for the outside world to becoming the supermarket to Asia and beyond.

SPEECH.PARA: Our former Prime Minister spoke in platitudes to Asia, of forming strategic alliances as World War III—the trade war—moved from the trenches to the negotiation table. The trouble is that only sound strategic policy outcomes can truly reap the potential of growth that has, without argument, emerged in trade, particularly within the Asian basin.

As a member who proudly presides over an electorate which significantly contributes to the agricultural industry, putting food on the nation's table and valuable dollars towards the national accounts with our beef, dairy produce and chickens, and the adjacent magnificent Hunter Valley wineries, I know the significance of having a clean, indeed green, agriculture and export food sector.
As John Howard said in an address to the National Farmers Federation on 21 November 1995:
The ability to balance scientific, economic and environmental considerations is now paramount if we are to create a model of sustainable rural development . . .

Rather than viewing climatic conditions solely on the basis of drought and flood, hail and rain falling at the wrong time, we must also build on positive approaches such as clean food marketing programs which are based upon Australia's relatively unspoilt environment.

And he is spot on. With the initiation of reforms to the growing Asian market and the potential growth in fresh and processed food exports—not just to Asia, but to other new world economic growth centres, including India, the Middle East, central and eastern Europe, as well as our more traditional markets of western Europe and North America—our natural advantage, with a clean agricultural sector, is second to none.

That is where the role of the AAHC will evolve. The Australian Animal Health Council emanated from the necessity to confront the delivery of animal health services in Australia, including the old chestnuts that previous and current legislators and bureaucrats had racked their minds over: the lack of cohesion and duplication of effort between the animal health services of the eight states and territories as well as an additional arrangement involving the Department of Primary Industries and Energy and the CSIRO.

Also, the lack of systematic involvement of industry generally in animal health issues has not assisted, given our status as an island nation, in its wish to keep out disease and effectively control it. The sensitivities and ever more complex and growing demands of international and domestic consumers for product safety and assurance in food seem to be forever rising.

Just a matter of weeks ago, evidence of diseased beef on the shop shelves in Japan was sending fractures through our exports of Aussie beef. At a time when our beef industry was already on the canvas it did not need another blow. On the domestic front, the salmonella in a recognised brand of peanut butter only highlighted how consumer confidence can wane—and rightfully so—if our agricultural sector does not continually get it right, from the farm site to the dining room plate.

The former government got it partly right with the evolution of EXANDIS in 1990. Formed to address the threat of exotic animal diseases, its primary objective, as outlined in its final report before it came under the umbrella of the AAHC, was to awaken Australians to the dangers of exotic diseases. It is the anticipation of our government and the intent of the legislation to maintain and further strengthen the nation's preparedness for virulent exotic diseases.

At the time this legislation was developed, the government was under intense pressure from the agricultural sector and agri‐industry to try for implementation by 1 July 1996, some two months ago. Raising the status of the package of reforms was unfortunately not achieved by ensuring that the levies would come into effect from the first day of the month and at least 30 days after the act commences, and by acknowledging that a retrospective application of levies will disadvantage producers, levy payers and intermediaries who collect the levies on the Commonwealth's behalf. A retrospective application would mean costs incurred are inevitably passed back onto industry. It will also impact on the funding of the AAHC as well as of associated industry bodies. The amendments halt the situation of cutting off your nose to spite yourself, by not allowing a lose‐lose outcome to occur.

EXANDIS was formulated with the principle of raising the level of our nation's—and, in particular, our agricultural sector's—preparedness for the outbreak of exotic diseases. The Australian Animal Health Council, as a non‐profit company limited by guarantee, importantly has a wider focus, jointly funded by the Commonwealth, the states and the peak national representative bodies of Australian livestock based industries. Minister John Anderson made this statement to the House on 9 May 1996:

The council's mission will be to ensure the Australian animal health services system is capable of maintaining acceptable national animal health standards which meet consumer needs and market requirements at home and overseas.

Awakening industry, all the way to the consumers themselves, and preparing it for the great threat of highly contagious exotic disease is but one matter. Allowing, without categorical evidence to the contrary, a window of opportunity to exotic disease to enter is something that does greatly concern industry and, I am sure, every member in this parliament.
EXANDIS pulled no punches in its summary of its operations in its final published report. In particular, page 12 of that report says:

The greatest threat to Australia is considered to be the highly contagious foot‐and‐mouth disease. An outbreak of FMD would have a devastating effect on the meat and meat product industries. Other serious threats are Newcastle Disease, blue‐tongue and classic swine fever. An outbreak of any of these diseases would incur heavy control, compensation and trade costs.

Speaking out for the local chicken growers, beef producers and farming families of Paterson, I have taken a perfectly solid stance, one that I am comfortable with, that an open door policy to disease is not my policy.

All this makes the success of the AAHC critical. Disease knows nothing of state or territory boundaries, let alone electorates or shires. Just as strategic direction in thinking is needed to avert the introduction of exotic diseases, by applying a strategic direction to the animal health service industry by utilising both private and public sector resources for the public good and by putting the structure in place for the AAHC to effectively operate, one must not let slide through to the keeper the critical role of the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service. The blowtorch has certainly been put to the belly of AQIS in recent times and, like all regionally based members, I will be looking on the imminent release of the Nairn committee of inquiry report into its operations with a great deal of interest.

BREAK.PARA: Just a matter of weeks ago, at the first public hearing of the Senate Rural and Regional Affairs and Transport Legislation Committee, whose terms of reference apply to the suggested acceptability of importing cooked chicken meat to Australia, Paul Hickey, the Executive Director of AQIS, again found that the organisation which he heads was before the parliamentarians with lots of questions. AQIS, of course, has undertaken full quarantine risk assessments of the very issue of cooked chicken imports arriving on our shores: a notion which I dispute and will take umbrage at on Friday of this week at the committee hearing in my electorate in Maitland.Mr Hickey said to the committee—and I do not dispute the point—that:

There are obligations that Australia and AQIS have in relation to the quarantine aspects of this (the importation of cooked chicken) and all other access issues. These obligations arise from Commonwealth legislation and Australia's commitment to the sanitary and phytosanitary agreement of the World Trade Organisation.
He went on:

First, our quarantine decisions must have a sound scientific and technical base. Second, our quarantine decisions must flow from a proper process of risk assessment. Third, AQIS must adopt a consistent approach to risk management—that being to adjust the acceptable risk from case to case. Fourth, access decisions must be designed to achieve the determined acceptable level of risk in the least trade restrictive way. Fifth, AQIS's decision making processes must be transparent and open, as a large net exporter of agricultural products.

What I do dispute, in line with what the AAHC is attempting to achieve, is AQIS's perception of risk management—to what level, to what stakes, it is willing to raise the game of risk of inadvertent green light policy to exotic diseases. The `no level of risk' as being the acceptable line has been disputed publicly as an impossible and intractable position to take by none other than the head of AQIS himself. I find the assessment, by the nation's official doorman to stop the possible exotic disease entry, somewhat confusing.

An assessment of the economic fallout from the virulent newcastle disease, done by none other than ABARE and using the Hunter and Western Sydney as models, found with imports of cooked chicken a decline of upwards of $37 million to the industry in the first year alone, that on the back of 40,000 tonnes of imports there was a loss to producers of $93 million and that on the back of 100,000 tonnes a staggering $169 million was lost.

The sense and sensibility of the situation—to use a turn of phrase from a recent movie—would be to get it right in the first place. So the AAHC should do its job, as this legislation allows it to do, and set about doing a better job more efficiently and with better resources.

I think there are a lot of questions relating to AQIS's role, its accountability and its accessibility which have been raised and which need to be answered. That is something that I will continue to pursue in the Main Committee and, indeed, in the Senate inquiry on Friday.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: O'Keefe, Neil, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy Speaker, as you know, the opposition is happy to see the Australian Animal Health Council (Live‐stock Industries) Funding Bill passed. In fact, most of the ideas and the content behind it were developed by the former Labor government. The approach that derives from it comes from our thinking, so it would be hardly likely that we would oppose it in this chamber.

SPEECH.PARA: I would just like to pick up on some of the comments from the honourable member for Paterson (Mr Bob Baldwin). I think it is quite evident that there is a very real awareness in Australia, that a spark has been lit, about the opportunity of getting clean, fresh food, particularly meat products, from the various industries that have export markets not just in Asia but also in some of our more traditional trading partners. Some of these markets have tended to have had less attention in recent years for a whole lot of reasons, but our attention should now be sparked up again—Canada is one country that I might mention. This is not just about maintaining acceptable animal health standards for consumer needs and market requirements for exports; it is also for our domestic consumer market.

One of the dynamics that is operating in Australia at the moment is the incredible surge in tourism that has taken place over the last 12 or 13 years, which brought many visitors. Those visitors inevitably return and when we go to their countries and speak with their senior ministers we find them constantly observing that their visitors to Australia continually remark on the clean, fresh air—pollution is an issue; they notice that there can be a difference—and on the quality and price of food in Australia compared with so many other countries around the world. So in our own markets it is important that we continue to develop this notion of presenting a wide range of very high quality foods for our restaurants, for our own homes and, of course, for export—not just for our own health and well being.

These levies, which are provided for under the various bills that are being debated cognately, play their role in enabling the Australian Animal Health Council to play its role in ensuring that all this comes together and maintains the standards.

In my own territory down in central Victoria, north of Tullamarine airport, probably the largest employer in the public sector in the region is meat processing. None of it is exported. Maybe there are some things to be done there to drive that further. We have had a very unfortunate experience of shonky operators causing works to be closed for quite a long time but they have now been reopened under much higher quality regimes and we are seeing a focus on the opportunities that are developing under this whole policy.

As I heard the honourable member mention, transport is one of the issues that we have to focus on. One of the sleepers for the industry is the question of packaging and the dynamics of new high‐tech packaging that will change the whole structure of transport. Just about anywhere you go in Australia, people are demanding an extension to their airport's runway so that they can land jets and have fresh food airfreighted straight into their markets, wherever they may be. I would postulate in this parliament that as we are building those runways, as we are building those cool stores, other parts of the industry are in fact developing very high‐tech long‐life fresh packaging which enables us to put that food, supermarket ready, into chilled containers that will go by land and sea bridge and arrive after anything up to 20 or 30 days in the transport cycle, ready for consumption, as if they had been picked or packed or processed just yesterday. So that is one of the things that will determine investment in these things.

The honourable member did mention the salmon industry. It is not directly related to the levies covered under this bill but I have to say that in my parliamentary role I had the great pleasure of visiting Nortas, a salmon processing operation in Mornington in Hobart, with the member for the area, the member for Franklin (Mr Quick). He is in the chamber today. I do compliment him on his approach to these businesses in his region. A day on the hustings with Harry and you come back with knowledge that is just astounding of the things that are going on and the foresight that is being shown down in Tasmania. I commend the member for Franklin for his efforts in this regard.

One of the key points that came through out of that visit to Nortas was a very deep concern in the salmon processing industry about the prospect of imports, particularly from Canada, being allowed by the government. In our time in government we did not accede to this request. We had it under review and we were genuinely leaning to the view that there was a risk of contaminated product arriving in Australia and of that product putting at risk our own industries. I think we have all been around this circle many times and we all well understand that, any time there is a question of competition from imports, one of the views the particular industry immediately puts on the table is that Australia has the highest standards in the world and we do not want to put them at risk from imports. And so we have actually had to become expert about assessing what is a real risk and what is simply a barrier against imports and competition.

I have no doubt that in the case of the fresh salmon industry the evidence is incontestable that overseas fresh salmon have a wide variety of diseases which may be quite acceptable and containable in their own environment but which are a major risk in our territory. We are learning, through the ballast water used in shipping, something we were completely unaware of until we started to observe it: that organisms coming from foreign waters bloom in Australian waters and create a risk to this kind of production.

Having started as a geographically isolated place, Australia is now more and more exposed to an international trading economy. We have to be genuinely careful about these sorts of issues, where they are a real risk and where they are perhaps a defence against competition from imports. It is important for our people to know that Nortas is concerned about competition from imports which may cause this problem. At the moment, we are cranking up a packaging, export and promotion campaign to build up the industry and to export from it. We have to understand that it cannot be competition from imports for the sake of it because we are in fact wanting these very countries to accept our products. Where we have a risk to our clean fresh food image that has to be seriously evaluated.

I call on the minister to take very seriously the representations from the industry. I certainly made the public pronouncement when I was in the region with Mr Quick that I would be recommending to our shadow spokesman in this field, Senator Collins, that we accept the veracity of the arguments and press the minister to place barriers against this imported fresh salmon product. I just used Nortas by way of example. I think we all understand the dynamics of competition and imports and exports. We all understand the dynamics of opening markets for ourselves and having to, on the other hand, open markets for others into Australia. That is the consequence of becoming an internationalised trading economy, which we are all very keen to do.

We know we have a spectacular product. We know we have the skills to develop it, market it and export it. We have to be very sure that, whether it is meat, fish or whatever, free exchange does not place at risk, in any way, the standard of our animals or our product. This legislation is designed to ensure that the Australian Animal Health Council plays that role. The principles behind it are supported by the opposition.

I threw in the example of Nortas in Tasmania by way of illustration that it is not just about meat products; it is also about a wide range of food products that Australian industry is becoming quite dynamic in in international terms and there is the need to provide it with that consideration. With those comments, I indicate that the opposition is quite happy to support this legislation.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tuckey, Wilson, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —This legislation is, in itself, attracting no criticism but it does, as the previous speaker has indicated, raise a lot of issues related to animal health and the means by which we protect the animals resident in Australia—be they fish, fowl or otherwise. It also raises aspects of the means by which we conduct our quarantine and export inspection services. All of these issues are ones of grave concern to me, representing probably the last remaining purely agricultural electorate in Australia. Certainly, it is the only electorate where the numbers of people directly associated with agriculture outnumber other groups in the electorate. This is a matter of grave importance to us.

SPEECH.PARA: It is an amazing situation throughout the small business arena today how certain costs, particularly those related to government activity, continue to rise. Of course, the market is not giving a similar rise in returns to agricultural producers or, for that matter, other small business producers. An example I looked at the other day shows that the sorts of rents that motel operators can attract in this day and age have not changed much in the last 10 years. I noted that, on a particular family property of that nature, in that same period, local government rates had doubled.

There are sections of the community that can charge any price they like by purely sending a letter in the mail and there are other sections, those dealing directly with the public or, in the case of agriculture, with importing countries, that do not have such an entitlement. In fact, the market prevails and, as I have said in this place before, there are just three questions: how good, how soon and how much? If you cannot meet all three of those criteria, they go elsewhere. So these are the issues that relate to these sorts of measures, because this is a measure to increase the amount of levy charged on a variety of producers—cattle, chickens and other sorts of livestock—to additionally fund the Australian Animal Health Council.

We are told that the quota industry is highly supportive of this proposal. That is another matter of grave concern to me because too often politicians classify `industry'—if I can use that in inverted commas—as a group of people in some commodity council, such as the Wool Council or the Grains Council or the AMLC or someone like this, when, in fact, in recent times, particularly in wool, they have demonstrated how distant they are from the grassroots of the organisation or the industry they choose to represent. I think it is time that we politicians make sure that when we bring these matters before the parliament and claim that they have `industry support' we recognise the industry as the people who actually write the cheques, not the half a dozen who get paid a fee to attend some commodity council meeting and commit their members to all sorts of costs which they have never been consulted about.

I would like specifically to take this opportunity to talk about the aspects of the costs that emanate from organisations of this nature, which we are funding today. I particularly want to look at AQIS and the fees and basis of its operation. It is no coincidence that in recent times I have had representations—and I could do without telephone calls being made at that level, thanks very much, Whip. Can you take that phone call somewhere else, Mark? I find this outrageous.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order!

—It is not suitable. I do not know why these telephones are around in the Main Committee room. When people are trying to make a speech they have to contend with blokes like you, shouting on the telephone. Anyway, the reality is that it should not happen.

SPEECH.PARA: Coming back to the address I want to make, which is pretty important, in recent times three issues have been drawn to my attention. The first relates to circumstances where an elector in my electorate chose to spend over $1 million building an export abattoir. He did so as an investment and by prearrangement some people had rented it from him to conduct the business. Apparently, these people were undercapitalised and within a reasonably short period—some months—were unable to continue the business. He had to take steps to have them evicted from the premises.

That sounds a pretty simple story, but there was one problem—at the end of that period they owed inspection fees of some $50,000, which AQIS attributes to the premises. This fellow wanted to either take the business over himself or install a new tenant and AQIS told him he could not do so until he paid the debts of his previous tenant.

When I approached the minister on this he said, `Oh well, that is what the industry wants.' I find that outrageous. My minister said, `That is what the industry wants.' We have a perfectly good facility, which would add competition to the marketplace in terms of buying livestock and processing it, all held up because AQIS finds it more convenient to collect its debts by this process, instead of having a proper process in place, whereby it deals with the person it licences and, if it has concerns about their financial capacity, it requires bonds or the like to be made available.

I call on the minister to put the necessary administrative processes in place to ensure that somebody who has invested in the industry and is creating the opportunity for jobs and everything else is not loaded up with the debts of someone totally outside their control. It is ridiculous, and it is the first example of what is wrong with the system.

The second one relates to fee structures. I have a constituent who has done almost the impossible. A relatively small pig producer, selling about a thousand pigs a year, running them open‐range and chemical free, he had the initiative to pack himself up, pay for a stand in a major food fair in Japan, take his little video over there and make some market contacts, which has resulted in a very important and high‐yielding niche market. He literally airfreights pig carcases to Japan at a profit. In fact, he has found it the mainstay of his business in the downturn that has occurred here in the pig industry in Australia. I want to come back to some of the reasons for that.

The reality is that, because the product is pork, he is not able to meet his Japanese buyer's demand to provide the buyer with a boned product. The reality is that, within Western Australia—and I would not be surprised if it occurred in other states—you cannot get any licensed export boning works to bone pork, because their principal business is mutton going into halal markets. Of course, to allow one hair of a pig inside those establishments would see them deemed off‐limits for future halal boning of mutton. He has managed to get them slaughtered, because that can be done in another works that deals with pigs on the domestic market. That is okay, but he cannot get them boned out by an export works.

The answer is, as I mentioned in the beginning, that he actually flies them out in carcase form. His buyer has to pay airfreight on all the bones, and he does not even want the skin on the product, in fact. Over there, apparently, that is the way they want it. So he has got to find a solution to this, and the only solution available is to have his own little boning works. Ideally, that should be built on his own property as a small slaughterhouse.

In terms of the size of the operation, that is not a problem. The licensing requirements are all about cleanliness and the make‐up of the facility. So, capital‐wise, that is not a problem. I must also say, in mentioning this, that the staff of AQIS with whom I have been dealing on this matter have been most cooperative. But, when I go to them to try and find out how they will be involved, they give me a sheet of paper that points out that to licence his works— which would be smaller than this room—the annual fee is $30,350. That is the fee. You can kill 10,000 pigs or you can kill 10 pigs, for the same price.

That is ridiculous. It is evidence of the lack of flexibility. We have got a bloke who has established his own market. We did not help him, Austrade did not help him, no‐one helped him; he has done it all himself. Now, at a time when he desperately needs this commodity, we are unable to say to him, `Well, that's the way it should go.'

Let me take that a step further. In terms of inspection, whilst AQIS are quite willing to licence the local vet, they still become the charging agent. They do not licence the vet and then let people deal with the vet in terms of fees, arrangements for visits and all that sort of thing. That vet has got to go and do four weeks study with AQIS and then come down as an employee or a subcontractor of AQIS. The going rate then is something like $65 an hour. It seems that there are other problems associated with that. It makes it totally uneconomical, and we have got to do something about it.

I cannot see why we cannot progress to a situation where AQIS is the provider of the regulatory program and the inspector of those people they license. When we look to the aircraft industry where Qantas is the only airline in the world to have achieved two world safest airline awards, we see that its planes are not inspected by government employees. The licensed aircraft maintenance engineer—the LAME—is an employee of Qantas, licensed by the government. Whilst someone might point to the general aviation industry where we had some problems with aircraft maintenance recently, the interesting point was that it was not the licensed aircraft maintenance engineers at fault. They were telling the people who license them—I call them the CAA, but they have had a number of names—that the actual neglect was in the licensing authority, so the system had worked. People are licensed and they act as both subcontractors and employees to guarantee the safety of those aircraft. As I once said when the royal commission was looking into meat inspection and substitution some years ago, if I had the choice between having an aircraft stop at 40,000 feet and a tummy ache, I know which one I would prefer.

The reality is that you can have an inspection system where government oversees it and the private sector pays the wages or it contracts out. I think it is time that AQIS went down that road and had as its employees just the upper echelon.

I want to take this a step further because the same issue applies with the export of wildflowers from my electorate—another great market, quite significant, all airfreight. I might add that it is a battle from Western Australia to get that space at very high rates. But why add to the problem by government inspection? We do not have a requirement for these things to be inspected on export but if you are going into the Japanese market, the Japanese will require it, so you need a certificate.

It is an interesting thing that quite properly AQIS has subcontracted the Western Australian Department of Agriculture to undertake this work on its behalf. If you were to export flowers, say, from Canberra to Perth they have to be inspected by the Western Australian Department of Agriculture and the fee is $25. The problem arises if you go along to that same inspector and ask him to certify flowers that you are exporting overseas on behalf of AQIS. The fee is $86 and double on weekends, by the same person. The state government can do the job for $25 but when AQIS hires the inspector the fee is $86.

There are other complications—which I will not go into now—when you try to get this service provided. It sort of doubles up. You can take a room full of flowers down to be inspected but if the airline says it will take only half today and the other half tomorrow you have to pay twice. We really have to look at this.

As the previous speaker mentioned, there is this grave concern we have with quarantine services at the other end of the proposal. Recently, a substantial import of canola seed was approved to Australia from New Zealand. It arrived substantially contaminated with a variety of weeds not existing at present in Australia—certainly not in Western Australia. The member for Murray (Mrs Stone) has just informed me that her electorate has a similar problem. The seeds got past the inspection authorities. There was apparently no growing out process to test what would come up when you put the seeds in the ground. Growers have bought this seed—it is apparently a superior variety of canola—planted it and gone back into their paddocks to find that they are half‐full of weeds that we have never seen before.

One might just wonder what we have the service for and how we can say, as we are saying with chicken meat and with fresh salmon imports, that we have an adequate service to guarantee that the diseases that are associated with the countries of origin in these two areas would not be imported into Australia. We know the sorts of results that can occur within my electorate at the moment and they are still trying to track it down.

We are seeing lupin paddocks decimated in the Mullewa region at this moment by a new fungus which has the opening word of `anthrax' in it. It is obviously not animal anthrax, but it is an anthrax type of fungus that is having, as the first person who rang me about it said, the same effect as spraying the lupins with 2‐4D. This fellow went into his paddock and thought that that was what must have happened. It just wiped the lupins out. It is very serious. It is his view that the original disease arrived in that district some time in 1963 with an uninspected importation of albus lupin seed. The outbreak was apparently dealt with at the time, but it has resurfaced 33 years later. It just gives you some indication of how careful we have to be.

I want to put this in another context in regard to pork. The pork industry in Australia is in severe financial difficulty, firstly, because of increased grain prices and, secondly, because of the competition being provided by subsidised pork coming out of Canada. It is fresh pork from a country where there are known diseases not known in Australia. At the time, many of us argued that this was sufficient reason to keep it out. The argument countering that was that there really was not sufficient risk and the Canadians were threatening to cut back on their Australian beef imports if we did not do something about it. So we granted the import of this pork. This has had a financial effect on the local industry and, as I recollect, the Canadians then cut the quota of Australian beef going into Canada—really matey. It proves the point.

Our problem is that we cannot, of course, go back on a scientific decision. You can change the tariffs and things like that, but once you have said that there is no risk in the importation of something and your science has proved it, you cannot go back next week and say, `We have rethought the situation and we think the risk is too great.' You are too late, and the Canadians know that. We get this sort of treatment all the time.

My pig exporter to Japan told me that the other day the Japanese just happened to put the import duty on his pork up to 40 per cent. There was no reason given other than that he was getting markets. Of course, at the moment, because of the silly arrangements we have here in Australia, he has to pay 40 per cent on the bones. We really do have to think about the way we manage these things if our country is to be competitive around the world. We have to make sure we protect the cleanliness of our livestock and the things that mean so much to us.

BREAK.PARA: There is a disease in grain in America—karmel bunc. I call it the foot‐and‐mouth disease of the wheat industry. Fortunately, at this stage of the game, our import restrictions are very strong in that regard. But it is double‐sided. How do we best ensure the competitiveness of our exporters? How do we best use the system to guarantee that there is no risk to our product?

The previous speaker talked about salmon, and he has my full endorsement. Years ago, I tried to assist my crayfish industry people by the importation of salmon heads. I became horrified by the types of diseases that could be introduced to Australian waters by allowing that to happen. In fact, to their credit, the authorities stuck out and demanded that only after irradiation could those salmon heads be brought in here as crayfish bait. I have to concur with the evidence that was eventually provided to me that that was worthwhile.
These are the issues I want to raise in relation to these matters. I thank the Main Committee.
Debate (on motion by Mr Ted Grace) adjourned.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Child Support Agency: Tax Refund Interception

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Mr Pyne

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Assistant Treasurer, upon notice, on 24 June 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) How many non‐custodial parents' tax refund cheques were not intercepted by the Child Support Agency (CSA) in 1994‐95 after the respective custodial parents had been advised that they would be receiving payments in arrears through the interception measure.
(2) What sum in arrears funding was not distributed to custodial parents because of the CSA's failure to intercept non‐custodial parents' tax refund cheques.
(3) What measures is the Government implementing to ensure that the failure referred to in parts (1) and (2) does not recur.

(4) Will the Government provide compensation to custodial parents who did not receive child support payments because of the CSA's failure to intercept tax return cheques; if so, when will the compensation be paid.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Costello, Peter, MP

TALK.START.PARA: — The Assistant Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable members question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Assistant Treasurer has indicated that Mr Pyne has provided further information to clarify the information sought in question (1) and this response addresses question (1) as clarified ie information relates to 1994/95 income tax returns lodged in the 1995/96 financial year.

(1) In the 1994/95 financial year the CSA identified 58 cases where it failed to intercept tax refunds, due to human or clerical error, which should have been intercepted (via the Tax Refund Intercept Program—TRIPS) to offset child support debts. In the 1995/96 financial year the CSA identified 76 cases where it failed to intercept tax refunds due to human or clerical error. In addition, a computer system error during the period 2 November 1995 to 17 November 1995 resulted in 3,546 income tax refunds issuing to payers which should have been identified and considered for interception. Generally, payees are not advised that they will receive payments in arrears through the interception measure. It would be normal to advise the payee in general terms that the CSA would intercept a refund if one became available.

(2) Although the CSA cannot provide the precise information requested it has identified that the financial loss incurred by custodial parents where the CSA failed to intercept tax refunds was $71 701 in 1994/95 and $141 053.03 in 1995/96.

(3) The non‐interception of refunds in November 1995 occurred as a result of a National Taxpayer System (NTS) program error. Branch offices in the agency were asked to take all possible action to recover the amount of the refund. Depending on the circumstances, action included cancelling cheques before they issued, placing a stopper on cheques, contacting the payer to arrange for the amount to be paid to the Agency and issuing a notice to banks requiring the bank to pay the amount of the child support liability to the Agency. New procedures have been put in place to ensure the same type of error does not occur again.

In addition, the staff instruction manual for the Tax Refund Interception Program (TRIPS) has been rewritten and issued to CSA client contact officers. Training for client contact staff in refund interception has been completed.

(4) In the 1994/95 financial year the CSA paid $71,701.00 in compensation claims for its failure to intercept tax refunds. In the 1995/96 financial year the CSA paid $141,053.03 in compensation claims.

A decision is yet to be made by the Child Support Registrar with regards to compensation for refunds not intercepted between 2 November to 17 November 1995. Further advice has been sought from the Attorney‐General's Department and a final decision is expected in the near future.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Evans, Martyn, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What steps are being taken to ensure that all computer systems in the Minister's Department or any agency or statutory authority for which the Minister has portfolio responsibility are modified so that they continue to operate properly after 1 January 2000.
(2) What is the estimated cost of the modifications.
(3) Will all systems be modified by 1 January 2000.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Dr David, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Department of Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs has commenced work on the analysis, modification and testing of all existing and planned IT systems in the portfolio to ensure they operate properly after 1 January 2000.

The Department's progress is being overseen and coordinated by a Departmental committee. The Department is actively making use of the experience and expertise gained across all APS agencies through membership of the Office of Government Information Technology (OGIT) Government Information Services Policy Board (GISPB) and Year 2000 sub‐committee.
Steps taken to date include:

PARA.TAB: raising staff awareness of the year 2000 issues;
conducting preliminary analysis of all IT systems;
establishing a formal committee in the Systems Division to oversee the year 2000 activities;
participating in the OGIT year 2000 survey;
contacting existing IT suppliers to ensure their products' readiness for the year 2000; and
seeking legal opinion on the amendment of all relevant contracts to ensure year 2000 compliance is a standard requirement of the contracts.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Lawrence, Carmen, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Resources and Energy, upon notice, on 20 August 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has his attention been drawn to a device known as a turtle exclusion device which can be fitted to fishing trawlers to prevent turtles forming part of the fishing by‐catch.
(2) Has his Department (a) evaluated the device-and (b) recommended that trawlers fit the device.
(3) What is the estimated number of turtles caught annually in the fishing by‐catch.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Anderson, John, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Resources and Energy has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Yes, I am aware of a range of different devices that are designed to exclude turtles from the nets of trawlers. Several of these turtle exclusion devices (TEDs) have been trialled to investigate the potential for their application in Australian fisheries. Devices that have been trialled include the Morrison soft TED and the Supershooter grid. Both of these TEDs are used in the Gulf of Mexico shrimp fishery. A Norwegian TED, the Nordmore grid, has also been trialled.
(2)(a) The Department of Primary Industries and Energy has not evaluated these TEDs. That function has been carried out principally by State agencies and the CSIRO.

Trials of TEDs were conducted in a joint project by the CSIRO Division of Fisheries, Australian Maritime College (AMC) and the Northern Territory Department of Primary Industries and Fisheries (NTDPIF) in February and March 1995. Several of the most promising TEDs were tested in the Gulf of Carpentaria to determine their effectiveness and suitability for Australian conditions. The results of these trials demonstrated that some TEDs were quite successful at substantially reducing the by‐catch of turtles and other large animals. However, the use of TEDs also reduced the catch of prawns. The project has now moved on to commercial trials of these devices through a joint project with the Queensland Department of Primary Industries (QDPI), AMC and the CSIRO.
Additional trials of TEDs such as the Morrison soft TED and the Nordmore grid and other types of by‐catch reduction devices (BRDs) have been conducted by NSW Fisheries, QDPI, and NTDPIF.

The QDPI and the NTDPIF are jointly developing a TED designed specifically for Australian conditions, the AusTED. This project has been funded through the Fisheries Research and Development Corporation (FRDC). The final report on the project is due in December.
(2)(b) My Department has not yet recommended that trawlers fit turtle exclusion devices for two reasons:

(i) Existing TEDs have been designed overseas to suit local conditions. Australian fisheries and fishing methods are different to those in other countries. Refinements of these devices are required to minimise the loss of prawns associated with their use and to make them suitable for Australian conditions.

(ii) Mandating the use of turtle exclusion devices could be counter productive and such action caused considerable conflict in the US fisheries. Without the cooperation of the fishing industry the cost of surveillance and enforcement of TEDs would be prohibitively high. This Government prefers to work in a cooperative manner with industry, environmental groups and State Governments. This approach allows us to catch our fisheries resources and protect our wildlife at the same time.

Such an approach has been used successfully in the NSW prawn trawl fisheries. Approximately 30% of the NSW offshore prawn trawl fishery use TEDs or other forms of BRDs on a voluntary basis. At times the majority of estuarine prawn trawlers in NSW use some form of TED or BRD such as the Nordmore grid on a voluntary basis to exclude jellyfish and other by‐catch species.

A $2 million program to encourage the voluntary use of by‐catch reduction devices (BRDs) including TEDs commenced in July 1996. The program incorporates a `gear library' of BRDs that the fishing industry may borrow to trial. The gear library will include the AusTED and a range of overseas TED designs that were trialled and refined in the Gulf of Carpentaria study. The gear library will allow these devices to be trialled under commercial fishing conditions and their performance will be documented by a research observer. The program will also include workshops held at different ports, and a range of educational materials such as videos and newsletters to carry the message. It will be available to trawlers in the Queensland east coast otter trawl fishery, the northern prawn fishery and the Torres Strait. The program is run jointly by the QDPI, AMC and the CSIRO. It is funded by the FRDC.

(3) I am advised that studies estimated the number of turtles captured by trawlers in the northern prawn fishery to be 5503 (424) in 1989 and 5238 (404) in 1990. Turtle captures in the northern prawn fishery and Torres Strait are dominated by flatback (59%), olive ridley (12%) and loggerhead turtles (10%).

Captures from the Queensland east coast otter trawl fishery were estimated at 5295 (1231) turtles annually between 1991 and 1992. The main species taken in the Queensland east coast trawl fishery are the loggerhead (50.4%), green (30.1%) and flatback turtles (10.1%).

Of these turtles approximately 750 in the northern prawn fishery and 50 in the Queensland east coast fishery were dead when brought aboard trawlers in 1990 and 1991. Some turtles were also comatose when brought aboard. Comatose turtles are allowed to recover on the deck for a period before being released. Subsequent mortality is unknown. However, if a worst case scenario is assumed in which all comatose turtles die, then a maximum of around 2,500 turtles of five species were killed annually in 1990 and 1991 by the use of trawls in northern Australia. A subsequent reduction of the fishing effort in the northern prawn fishery would have decreased the number of turtle deaths there by an estimated 30% since 1991.

In contrast, the indigenous harvest of green turtles in Torres Strait and southern Papua New Guinea has been estimated at 5,200 to 6,300 turtles per year. The annual catch of the Indonesian commercial fishery is estimated to be in excess of 70,000 green and hawksbill turtles per year.

ANSWER.TO.QON.TITLE: Training: Textile, Clothing and Footwear Employees

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Thomson, Kelvin, MP

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs, upon notice, on 21 August 1996:

QUESTION.PARA: Will the Government honour the commitment of the former Government concerning the provision of training for former textile clothing and footwear employees made redundant as a result of industry restructuring, and in particular for those former employees currently enrolled at the John Batman Institute of Technical and Further Education.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Kemp, Dr David, MP

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment, Education, Training and Youth Affairs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

ANSWER.PARA: The Government determined, as part of the 1996‐97 Budget, that the Textile Clothing and Footwear Labour Adjustment Package (TCF LAP) would cease on 31 August 1996.

This decision means that from 1 September 1996 the Commonwealth Employment Service is not able to approve further training courses, wage subsidies or relocation assistance under the TCF LAP. Those who are already receiving assistance (such as a training course) under the program must complete that assistance by 31 December 1996. All forms of assistance under TCF LAP will cease from 31 December 1996.

The Government had to consider very carefully the different forms of assistance available to unemployed workers and to rationalise and optimise those various arrangements. The range of labour market programs is currently being simplified and streamlined to facilitate access. The new arrangements will be implemented from October 1996.
Former TCF workers who may otherwise have received TCF LAP assistance will be able to seek assistance under other labour market programs.

There are 29 former TCF employees currently undertaking training courses under TCF LAP at the John Batman Institute of Technical and Further Education. Every person in this group will be able to complete his/her course as all courses are due to finish by 31 December 1996.
